—Has the attention of the Deputy Prime Minister been drawn to an article in the Australian Financial Review of 7 September concerning a resources development and supply conference in Sydney and to what was reported to have been said there by Mr Imai of Nippon Steel Corporation who, amongst other things , was critical, so it appears, of Australia's high costs and growing reputation for unreliability as an exporter? Can the Deputy Prime Minister tell the House the implications for the future prosperity of this country of increases in costs in our export industries, particularly iron and coal, and the increase in our growing reputation for unreliability as an exporter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the actual report but it has been brought to my attention that concern was expressed by some of the Australians at the conference about the possibility of declining imports by Japan of our iron ore and coal. I think one has to recognise the realities of the situation in that the Japanese steel industry looks like going through its lowest production year for the last 11 years. This is because of both lower consumption in Japan and lower export possibilities. That is affecting our sales of iron ore from Western Australia and coking coal from the eastern States. What Australia has been advocating in making representations to Japan is that there should be a sharing of any decline in the imports of raw materials. We have developed a very substantial iron and coal exporting industry in parallel with the growth of the Japanese steel industry. If there are any reversals we would want to see the same equitable proportion going to Japan as we have traditionally had.

ANSWER.PARA: At the Australia-Japan Ministerial Committee meeting that we had recently I made the point very cogently that we did not want to see our percentage share of the market being lost. Traditionally we have had about 48 per cent of the iron ore market. It is a bit lower than that this year and we would like to see that picked up. Traditionally, we have been getting from 50 per cent to 55 per cent of the coking coal market. So concerned is Western Australia about the matter that its Minister for Resources Development was in Japan only last week pointing out that if Western Australia were to get any lesser share of the market it would seriously jeopardise the economic operations of its iron ore exports.

The Premier of New South Wales is also very concerned about the matter. At the moment he is in Japan and will be making similar representations. I think the greatest damage that has been done to our reputation over the last year was caused by the surge of industrial disputes and problems. They led to shipping delays. Fortunately in New South Wales there has been some reprieve from that situation. The long waiting time, resulting in heavy demurrage paid on ships off Newcastle and Port Kembla, has been eased. There has been a responsible response from the unions as a result of discussions between governments and the industry. I am hoping that the unions will recognise how important it is that from now on they maintain the orders that they have; that they try to reinstate the reliability of Australia as a dependable exporter. I cannot emphasise that enough. At present, when there are difficult export circumstances around the world, Australia has to struggle to its utmost to maintain its competitive position, and reliability plays an important part.

I point out to the House also that the cost of passage of these people will have to be borne by the migrants or by their sponsors in Australia. PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's out-of-hand and counter-productive rejection of the ACTU proposals for attempting constructively to address the problem of unemployment in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke Mr R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, in the atmosphere of last week's growing public outcry against the Government's reprehensible conduct in respect of the tax avoidance industry, which had been so starkly revealed in the fourth interim report of Commissioner Costigan, there may have been a tendency to overlook another disastrous illustration of why the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Government are no longer entitled to the respect and confidence of the people of this country. On Thursday and Friday of last week the Australian Council of Trade Unions held a federal unions conference, and out of that two- day conference there emerged a resolution of historic significance. I remind the House that such a conference of federal trade unions conducted by the ACTU between biennial congresses is the most representative way of testing the will of the trade union movement in this country. Out of that conference there emerged a resolution which I say is deserving of earnest consideration by the Government. I ask members of the House to bear in mind precisely what was said in that resolution which, following the federal unions conference was endorsed by the Executive of the ACTU. In particular I ask that the first paragraph of the resolution be borne clearly in mind. The trade union movement of Australia, so assembled, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The causes of unemployment are manifold and as recognised in policy are not capable of simple solution. The following proposal does not pretend to be a panacea for all our economic problems nor will it create by itself full employment.

Right at the outset of that resolution which was passed by the federal unions conference and subsequently endorsed that day by the Federal Executive of the ACTU was a responsible statement starting off with the proposition that the causes of unemployment are manifold; that the ACTU did not have all the answers and that it did not pretend to put forward a panacea in regard to this matter. Let me read further from what the ACTU, so assembled, said in respect of this fundamentally important matter. It also acknowledged in its resolution the significance in part of some things that are contained in the Budget. In other words, it was not simply trying to condemn the Federal Government totally out of hand, saying that nothing of relevance had been done. Indeed, the resolution stated:

The income tax changes announced in the 1982-83 Budget satisfy the wage and salary earners demand for tax indexation and as such they alleviate the need for unions to build income tax increases into claims for cost of living adjustments.

Again that is a thoroughly responsible and constructive approach by that assembling of the Australian trade union movement. It recognised that what happened in the Budget in respect of tax indexation met that part of its claim. As I said at the outset, there is first of all a responsible recognition that the trade union movement did not have all the answers and that the causes of unemployment were complex. Secondly, the ACTU pointed out that it took positive account of what the Government had done in the Budget. It went on to make very specific proposals about what could be done, on its part as well as by the Government, co-operatively, to try to deal with the problems confronting this country in general and in respect of unemployment in particular. It said:

We do not believe that the trade union movement can be expected to make the only contribution and for this reason there should be a collective response involving: (a) forgoing half the benefits of tax indexation (which means $4 per week at average weekly earnings level).

The ACTU went on to refer to the other matters which would be involved in such a comprehensive package. I again remind you, Mr Speaker, and the House of the context. The ACTU asserted that it did not have all the answers and that the causes of unemployment were complex; it recognised positively the contribution that the Budget has made in respect of tax indexation-that that had met the ACTU 's part of the negotiations that it had had with the Government-and from that totally positive and responsible approach it went on to make a specific proposal about how the ACTU and the rest of the community could make a sacrifice by forgoing half the amount of tax indexation to create a national employment fund which would be directed, on the part of the ACTU which had made the sacrifice and the rest of the community, to helping those in the community who were currently unemployed. That was the decision-an historic decision-that was taken by the ACTU on Friday of last week. The whole context of the debate and the resolution showed on the part of the ACTU realism, responsibility and flexibility.

What was the response by this Government to that decision and attitude of the ACTU? The most convenient way of referring to the expressed reaction of the Government is to go to the Age of last Saturday. Under the heading 'Fraser scorns unions' job deal' we have a report on the reaction of the Government. The article stated:

The ACTU's offer to give up half the Budget tax cuts in return for a big job creation scheme was rejected by the Federal Government yesterday, only hours after it was approved by more than 150 unions.
Let us look at the very specific language of the rejection made by this Government. The article stated:
The acting Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Brown, described the plan as a 'mild form of lunacy', hare-brained and absurd.

This was the reaction of the then Acting Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations to this positive proposal involving a sacrifice of half of the indexation cuts. The response by the Acting Minister was that the plan was a mild form of lunacy, hare-brained and absurd. If we are properly to understand the hypocrisy and the recklessness of this Government do not let me immediately rely on my saying on behalf of the Opposition what judgments should be made about this sort of response by the Government. Let me briefly refer to the range of editorial reaction to this response of the Government. Firstly, I go to the Australian Financial Review of Monday, 6 September. It stated:

Instead of attacking the employment creation plan put forward by the Australian Council of Trade Unions last week it would do the Government and others more credit if they were prepared to realise how far the majority of unions in the ACTU have moved towards a rational approach to Australia's economic problems.
The article went on:

It is one of the great political faults of the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, that his instinct to kick a political head when he sees it prevents him from realising how far the ACTU has in fact moved towards genuine social compromise in the scheme put forward last week.

With an election looming in the not too distant future it is probably not surprising that the Prime Minister should not be willing to concede that the ACTU has travelled a long way along the path of reasonable compromise . . . If the Prime Minister were genuinely interested in consensus in the matter of wages policy he ought to recognise how far the ACTU has moved.
Let us look at the Canberra Times of the same date. What was its reaction to the plan? It stated:
The Government has chosen to characterise it as ''lunacy'', and to reiterate that wage increases are the root cause of unemployment. That is the sort of simplistic rhetoric that gets us nowhere.
The article went on to state:

. . . it has been hasty in dismissing it out of hand. That looks like a slap in the face to people prepared to drop their customary, hard adversarial role and try for real negotiation. It could lead to a very damaging standoff.
The Canberra Times said that the Government should accept:
. . . that the ACTU has offered a genuinely useful set of proposals for negotiation . . .
We come to what yesterday's Age had to say. It stated:

The insulting way in which the Fraser Government rejected the ACTU's economic plan on Friday permits only one conclusion: that the Government is now more concerned about election tactics than economic management . . . There has been a growing recognition on all sides that Australia must learn from the consensus policies of the countries that have weathered the recession best . . .

In these circumstances, one would have thought the Government would recognise- as anyone concerned with the issue must recognise-that the ACTU's proposal was a very bold step towards such a consensus . . . This is a big and courageous step for the ACTU to make, and it deserved a warm reception from the Government . . . The Acting Minister, Mr Brown, consulted Mr Fraser, who saw it as merely a threat to the Government's campaign strategy for an early election.
The Age went on to say:
On his leader's instructions, Mr Brown not only rejected the offer, but did so in such a derisory manner as to suggest to the ACTU that it should not bother in future.
The editorial continued:
This is an abysmal way to run an economy.
It concluded:

. . . the Fraser Government has slammed the door on the union moderates seeking consultation. By virtually telling them not to come back, it has given carte blanche to unions with industrial muscle to get what they can, while those lacking muscle fall behind.
In respect of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Macphee), who is at the table, the Age had this to say:
The unfortunate Mr Macphee may as well extend his holidays. There seems little point in negotiating an agreement when your principal wants a confrontation.

There is the wide range of reaction from the Australian Financial Review, the Canberra Times and the Age condemning the Government. What they said and indeed what we say here is not that the ACTU proposals are necessarily perfect and without the possibility of criticism, nor is it suggested that the ACTU would make that claim itself. What was universally recognised in those editorials was that here was a really constructive, positive approach along the road to consensus, a recognition on behalf of the trade union movement that wages can play some part in the creation of economic problems including unemployment. They recognised on the part of the trade union movement an openness, a frankness, a holding out of the hand and saying: 'Look, we know that what we do can have some impact upon what happens to other people. It can have an adverse impact. What are we doing? We are acknowledging that and acknowledging that part of the Government's Budget was helpful in regard to the tax indexation claim. We are positively saying that we are prepared to forgo a half of the tax indexation that has been offered. Why? We believe that in that way we, as a trade union movement, can try constructively to do something to help those who are unemployed'. What do the unions get for their pains? They get this condemnation that they are engaged in lunacy and hare-brained approaches. Is it any wonder that the Age, the Australian Financial Review and the Canberra Times condemn this Government and say that it was putting electoral advantage and perceived political advantage in front of the proper management and conduct of industrial relations of this country?

I say to my friend the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Macphee) at the table-I use those words 'my friend' advisedly-that the time has come when he must stand up and be counted on this issue. Is he going to repudiate publicly this offensive nonsense which, by general consensus, is seen to run counter to the best interests of this country? I simply cannot believe that the Minister endorses the approach of the Prime Minister and of the Minister for Communications, who on this occasion readily filled the role of malleable monkey for the organ grinder from Nareen. TALK.START.PARA: — The relationship between the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions just cannot be looked at in isolation in terms of the events of one week. I remind the House of the fact that on 7 July a tripartite conference was held at the request of the ACTU, agreed to by the Government with the employers, to consider what ought to be in the forthcoming Budget and what the interests of both sides of the industrial fence were. The ACTU put some very elaborate and certainly very constructive propositions to us. It actually made public a resume of what had been put on that occasion. In fact, if one drew up a table of what it put and what we have responded to in this Budget one would find that we have actually met all of its principal demands. Its demands did not contain a reference to the kind of so-called national employment fund which it announced last Friday.
—The Budget did not contain the drought proposal either. You are not prepared to adapt to changing circumstances?

—I am merely trying to be kind to the honourable member for Wills on this occasion. Clearly the drought proposals are the result of a worsening climatic situation; regrettably the unemployment situation has been with us for some time. We on the Government side have said that we do not in any way welcome the high levels of unemployment. We are doing what we can. We have said in many debates in this House, including one a couple of weeks ago, that we are trying to contain and reduce those high levels of unemployment. We sought the support of the ACTU in those measures. The ACTU had two opportunities before the Budget- the last of them was on 7 July-to put views about employment and unemployment. It did not do so.

SPEECH.PARA: What has to be recognised is that the proposition now put by the ACTU, while it has the commendable features that the honourable member for Wills has pointed out, also has the commendable feature that the trade union movement of this country now acknowledges the importance of helping to curb unemployment and create employment. It also acknowledges that while it has not got all the answers and certainly is not fully responsible, it does bear some responsibility for improving that picture. It has that advantage and I can acknowledge that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you repudiate what your Acting Minister said?

—I will come to that in a moment. The practical observation which the honourable member for Wills chose to ignore is: How does one, three weeks after the Budget is presented, respond to that kind of argument? Is the ACTU, for example, powerful enough to say to its members: 'Sign on the dotted line. Sign away half your tax reduction'? Are those 50 per cent or more of persons in the work force who are not unionised going to have the ACTU speaking for them? Will they say: 'Yes, we are quite happy because there has been a Federal unions meeting and someone has decided on our behalf that we will forgo our tax reductions in the Budget'? What the Acting Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr N.A. Brown) did say and what the honourable member chose to ignore was contained in the last paragraph of the Acting Minister's Press release. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: If the ACTU wishes to have discussions with Government on the proposals it has put forward, then the Government is willing to do so. However, such discussions would need to be on the clear understanding of the importance the Government attaches to wage restraint in present economic circumstances.

The importance of that statement is that as a precondition, as it were, for this kind of national employment fund-a precondition for co-operation, so it seems, reading the ACTU's release-there was a commitment sought from the Government to support the maintenance of real wages. There were several references on the wages policy side to a precondition that the Government must agree to a centralised system of wage fixation which guaranteed indexation of wages. The Government made it clear that in the current economic circumstances that was not on. While I again congratulate the ACTU on getting this far, nevertheless one sees a great deal of vagueness in this quite extensive document. In fact, I have spoken by telephone to the President of the ACTU and said that when he thinks it is useful I would be pleased to have a yarn with him and any of his officials on what the plan means. We are agreed that the most useful thing for him to do now is to go, as he was asked to do by the meeting of last Friday, to the peak councils in the States-the trades and labour councils-and when he has completed that exercise we will have a discussion on what the document means.

I do not presume to quote the President but I think he would acknowledge the difficulty as is illustrated in that famous expression about the ink not being dry. When the Budget has been presented, what the ACTU has now put could not reasonably be entertained by the Government. It is hardly surprising that the recommendations put forward, both administratively and in terms of the principle of the Budget, cannot be accepted. But it is significant that, however belatedly the trade union movement generally, as distinct from some of its leaders, now acknowledges the seriousness of unemployment, the fact is that to some extent that situation is worsened and has been brought about by some of the actions of some of the militant trade union leaders in respect of excessive wage demands and hours reductions. It is a matter about which they could be concerned and should be concerned.

It is very important too to note that the national employment fund, even if it were feasible to administer, would amount to an extra cost of some $785m. Admittedly this is to be taken away from certain other taxpayers who would believe they need it and whom we believe will use it effectively. The Senior Vice-President of the ACTU puts the number of persons who might be trained under the scheme at only some 40,000 in the next six months and perhaps as many as 120 ,000 within a year. No government can seriously consider in isolation that sort of proposition as opposed to the care which went into the preparation of this Budget which is aimed, of course, at helping to retain present levels of employment, improve the real disposable income of people and in fact to restore our economic growth.

The ACTU has at last recognised the unemployment situation. Let us not forget that the Australian Labor Party overlooked unemployment in the preparation of its policy for its biennial congress. In fact, both sides of the labour movement have been rather remiss on the question of unemployment whereas the Government has consistently expended increasing sums Budget by Budget on training programs designed to give people a level of skill for permanent employment. It is also worth noting that the Victorian Premier is now reported to be seeking to break some election commitments that he made on employment subsidisation. Whilst I do not know whether he has made a firm statement on this matter, there are reports in today's Press indicating that he is interested in breaking that election commitment. One of the most important aspects of that is that glib statements are made sometimes by trade union officials and Labor politicians about the gravity of unemployment and the fact that somehow or other the Government has to produce a magical answer. I think the ACTU and the Opposition have to recognise that the time for putting these views forward is prior to the preparation of the Budget. Having said that, I certainly will look forward to a detailed discussion with the ACTU on its proposals, to try to put some flesh on the bones and to see how relevant they might be in the preparation of the next year's Budget.

There is no doubt that the trade union movement has come a long way in recognising the unemployment situation and the fact that there is a link between excessive wage increases or labour costs and unemployment. At this stage I believe it would be irresponsible for us to support the proposition for indexation of real wages. I believe that the ACTU and its members should look at the benefits that this Budget brings to them on 1 November. They should then make an assessment of what they believe might be done in the next year's Budget. No proposal of this nature was put to us in the tripartite discussions. I do not think that any reasonable person, including the editorialists, can expect the Government now, three weeks after the presentation of the Budget, to respond to a proposition of that nature.

If there was to be a federal union meeting one would have hoped it would have been before the tripartite conference. The date for the tripartite conference was set a good month before it was held and it was set to suit the convenience of the ACTU leadership. The statement by the ACTU on the mechanics of the fund to which reference has been made-indeed, it seems to me that the honourable member for Wills relied solely upon that fund-do not provide detail. They would not provide detail if he were in government trying to administer the fund. I have asked the ACTU when we do have our discussions to spell out what it wants to operate. Certainly as I read it now the Government would have to say to pay- as-you-earn taxpayers 'We are going to change our mind and call back the PAYE scale to take effect on 1 November'. This would be costly. It would be time consuming. It would mean that many people who are not affiliated with the ACTU and who would not want the ACTU speaking for them would say: 'Wait a minute, the Government is in breach of faith as far as I am concerned'.

The whole proposition is just too silly. The timing is quite absurd. I suggest that the wrath, or sense of frustration, which was felt by the Prime Minister ( Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Acting Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations owed itself to that. For the first time, a constructive tripartite discussion was held. All three parties told the Press how constructive and useful it was. The Prime Minister said that he and his Ministers took on board what the ACTU had to say and that its views would be reflected in the Budget. They were very clearly reflected in the Budget. On the night the Budget was brought down it was described as horrible. Three days later the ACTU had to put out a statement which showed, as the honourable member for Wills has acknowledged today, that the Budget had a number of good features which met things its members were concerned about. It had many good features and very few irritating features the more that members of the ACTU took the time to examine it.

At last Friday's meeting the ACTU produced some idea of a new employment creation fund. That idea was not advanced to us before the Budget, and it is clearly something which requires Budget implementation. It would require a complete rewriting of this Budget if we were to try to cope with it now. The idea has been thought through no better than some of the plans that have come from the ALP over the years for the creation of jobs by subsidisation, without any certainty that people would be employed for any real length of time and not at the expense of other people. No matter how one looks at this proposal, there are many more questions to be asked than are answered in the ACTU's document. I do not believe that it will be able to provide within the next few months a detailed program which would be capable of implementation. I do not believe, in other words, that had the ACTU put the idea to us on 7 July we could have got it into the sort of shape required in time for this Budget. I welcome the fact that the ACTU is concerned at last about the relationship between wage increases and unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —When is the Government going to do something about unemployment? It has had seven years.

—This Government, through its policies of economic management, which have been referred to in many debates in this House, in terms of employment creation and training for permanent employment has done more than any other government.
—You have reduced the funds by 35 per cent in real terms.

—That is not so. There has been a dramatic increase in the funds available for all training and employment programs. I look forward to a serious discussion with the ACTU when it has completed discussions with its trades hall councils. We will then do our best to try to accommodate its latest idea in a practical way in next year's Budget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —In seconding the discussion of the matter of public importance brought forward by the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke), it is interesting to note that at last we have had a statement, or at least a few words, from the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Macphee ) on the subject of employment. There is not much doubt from what he said that he does not agree with the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Minister for Communications (Mr N.A. Brown), who was acting in his place while he was away having a holiday. To put this matter into perspective, we need to look at some of the things that have happened since the Budget. On 24 August the Prime Minister was asked this question in this House in relation to the Budget:

SPEECH.PARA: What does the Budget do that will provide incentives to those making claims for increases in wages, particularly unions, to diminish those claims?
The Prime Minister said:
There is a very substantial incentive in the Budget to moderate wage claims as a result of the totality of the measures that the Government introduced.

The honourable member for Wills indicated that the trade union movement in deliberations at its conference recognised that some of the things that were done in the Budget were of benefit to the union movement. The Prime Minister also said:

I believe it is reasonable, and the Australian Council of Trade Unions has recognised that it is reasonable, to think that this establishes a precondition for wage restraint through the course of this year.

That was said on 24 August, and I started to believe that perhaps the Prime Minister was learning that a consensus approach could work. However, it did not last long. As the honourable member for Wills clearly indicated, on 3 September when the ACTU approached the Government on this matter there was an immediate reaction. The confrontation approach took over while the Minister was absent and another Minister was taking his place. Clearly, the Prime Minister scorned the unions job deal. The Acting Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations described it as a mild form of lunacy, as the honourable member for Wills has said. The immediate reaction of this Government to a genuine attempt to do something about employment problems in this country was to attack it on a confrontation basis. From a few days after the Budget when there was a slight softening of the confrontation approach we went back into it full bore, while the Minister was away.

We are putting forward today the argument that there was an out-of-hand rejection. The honourable member for Wills has clearly indicated that. The statements that were made and the way in which they were reported in the Press were clearly seen by the public and the media in this country as indicating that a sensible proposal put forward for discussion had been rejected out of hand. It was a counter-productive rejection. Either we have a common sense approach in this country in negotiations on wages and conditions and dealings between governments and unions or we continue with the sorts of confrontation policies we have had for the last seven years, and which are counter-productive. They will not do anything for the stability of the economy in this country. They will not do anything for the problems of unemployment in respect of which the ACTU was trying to put forward proposals. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, who is at the table, has told us in statements on the Budget that we can expect unemployment to rise next year to 8 per cent, an increase of 40 per cent to 50 per cent over this year. He announced those figures in speeches following the Budget but when the trade union movement comes together and presents a plan for discussion the Government's approach is a confrontationist counter-productive rejection of the proposal.

The problems of unemployment will not go away. The Minister said that a tripartite conference was held on 7 July so that the unions could sit down with the Government and put their claims before the Budget was brought down. The Government claims that it met the princpal demands, but it completely ignored any proposals on job creation. The Budget has clearly indicated that people will be out of work in greater numbers than ever before. The Government has come forward with no proposals for jobs. It claims that it is doing things for job training. There is not much point in the Government's putting money into job training when it is not prepared to put something towards creating jobs. The trade union movement made a genuine attempt. The union came together and said to the Government: 'We are prepared to put forward a plan whereby $725m of the tax indexation concessions can be used to create employment, to establish a national employment fund.' The Government is completely ignoring that proposal. It is using the work force as a tool for inflation control and doing nothing to counter the effects of unemployment on the families of this nation.

Let me get back to the matter of vital importance. The Minister first of all acknowledges that the proposals have some merit. He congratulated the ACTU on the document. He told us that he has spoken to the ACTU President and that he is prepared to negotiate and talk about employment problems with the trade union movement. What a complete opposite is the Minister's attitude to the initial reaction by the Prime Minister and the Acting Minister, who went to the Prime Minister and got the okay to issue his statement to the Press. Fancy any Minister, the day after a proposition is put forward to a government, saying that it is a mild form of lunacy, hare-brained and absurd! At the end of his Press release the Minister said that perhaps the Government could talk about it. This is the type of approach we have seen for seven years.

It will never do anything for the economy of Australia. If we really want to see the sorts of problems this has created in the past and will create in the future, particularly for this Minister, we only have only to go back to 28 April 1981 and the resignation of the former Minister for Industrial Relations, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). What he said then is relevant right now. He said:
Two things are relevant. First, effective industrial relations in this country have been put at risk by the undermining of the authority of the responsible Minister.

It was not a bad effort last week of the Prime Minister and his Acting Minister, while the Minister responsible was on holiday for a couple of days, to take the opportunity to undermine him completely. The former Minister continued:

Second, the nation requires a steady and responsible conduct of its affairs, and especially in the extremely significant area of industrial relations. As my predecessor and I have frequently said, it is fundamental that the power of government in the field of industrial relations be used with fine judgement.

I wonder how long it will be before we find the present Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, who is at the table, in the very same position in which this Minister found himself, being undermined by a Prime Minister who is interested only in confrontation and who is not interested in the unemployed of this country. The former Minister went on:
This is especially so in an outmoded system of industrial relations unsuited to the shift of power between capital and labour.

Mark my words, those statements made on 28 April 1981 when another Minister of this Government resigned will definitely come back to the mind of this Minister. I challenge him here and now to repudiate those statements made by the former Minister and I challenge him and other speakers on the Government side, especially the next speaker in this debate, the honourable member for Connor (Mr Tuckey), who as usual is ready to have a go at the unions, to state publicly what this Government's position is going to be. Will he follow the Minister at the table, who presented logic and common sense and said that he intended to speak with the union movement? Or will he argue on the side of the Prime Minister and the Acting Minister who treat this matter as a confrontation contest at all times?

The unemployed of this country, who are estimated by the Minister at the table to be 8 per cent of the work force this year, are waiting for this Government to come up with a policy. The trade union movement has come forward with a sensible proposal. We have heard the Minister say that he is prepared to talk. We have heard the Prime Minister and the Acting Minister clearly scorn what the trade union movement did. This Government has to make up its mind what its policy on the unemployed is. Does it want confrontation and more problems or will it take a consensus line and talk sensibly to the union movement about the massive problems that come to any country which has 8 per cent unemployment and half a million people who cannot receive a job or a wage?

PETITION.TITLE: National Estate Areas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the lack of effective Federal environmental protection legislation and urge that suitable legislation be enacted immediately.

Your petitioners are concerned that National Estate areas such as South West Tasmania, the Great Barrier Reef and the Western Australian Jarrah Forests cannot be fully protected until adequate legislation exists and is enforced. Your humble petitioners therefore call upon the House of Representatives to ensure that all provisions of the Heritage Act and the Environment Impact of Proposals Act are fully complied with in respect of National Estate Areas. In particular your petitioners call upon you to adopt the recommendations of the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment on South West Tasmania. Your petitioners believe that this is a national issue and must be resolved by the action of the Federal Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Coleman and Mr Connolly.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The heart-rending loss of homes by home purchasers, due to an expanding holocaust of interest rates caused by, and to quote the manager of a leading bank (26.4.81) 'with the growing competition for savings, depositors are looking for higher interest returns on deposits. In order to retain our depositors and to meet the increased costs payable on deposits and operating expenses; it is necessary to raise income from loans of all types, including House Loans.'

Therefore it becomes transparently clear that the constant edging up of interest rates for investors by banks, lending institutions, and banking consortiums are collectively responsible for the monetary explosion, lack of employment and all that that entails and is causing grave social disruption to hundreds of thousands. Behind it all, the absence of control that is now politically essential in the interest of justice and fair distribution of burden .
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your House urge all politicians to unite nationally to do all within their power to reduce interest rates across the board.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Day
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the 26th January, 1788, is the date of first white settlement in Australia , and therefore marks the beginning of modern Australia,
and this event marks the most appropriate date on which to celebrate our national day.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament will determine that Australia Day is to be celebrated on the twenty-sixth day of January each year, and that a public holiday will be declared on that day, regardless of which day of the week is the 26th.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Wine Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
(a) that wine is a beverage of moderation whose use especially in conjunction with food may be beneficial to the consumer.
(b) that per capita consumption of alcohol in Australia has stabilised at 9.6 litres per head, the same as the average over the past eight years.
(c) that the low retail price of wine in Australia has been brought about by a number of factors including an oversupply of grapes and grape products.
(d) that if the price of wine is increased due to factors outside the control of grape growers, wine makers and retailers, sales of wine will be reduced.
(e) that the consequent fall in the demand for grapes coupled with the reduced wine production will affect employment and incomes, particularly in rural areas.
(f) that Australian brandy continues to lose market share to other spirits.

Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Government consider and appreciate the complexities of the widely-spread Australian Wine Industry and be aware that any Government impost will cause further imbalance between the supply of and the demand for grapes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
(a) that the Australian Government signed the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women in Copenhagen in 1980;
(b) that the Convention came into force on 3 September 1981;

(c) that Australian women suffer serious disadvantage in employment, education, accommodation, membership of licensed clubs, provision of goods and services including services relating to banking, insurance and the provision of grants, loans, credit or finance;

(d) that this disadvantage could be overcome by (i) making unlawful certain discrimination on the grounds of sex and marital status, (ii) eliminating discrimination on the ground of sex and marital status and (iii) promoting affirmative action for women in employment;
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Parliament pass the Sex and Marital Status Discrimination Bill 1981.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Price of Petrol
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia ( electors of the division of Grey) respectfully showeth:

That the recent seeking or granting of increases to the wholesale maximum price of petrol is recognised as an artificial means to enable oil companies to maintain their present profit levels, and the Federal Government to also retain its present high level of petrol excise through parity pricing of our oil, a stealth tax, against the predicted decline of the O.P.E.C. world oil prices.

This artificial tax and price increase imposed upon our oil (Aust. imports only 3 per cent of its oil requirement) by the Federal Government and oil companies, affects the whole of the economic structure of the Australian consumer, commercial and agricultural sectors. The stimulation this tax and price has upon hidden and indirect taxation, far surpasses any tax effect from any other single item essential to the welfare and living standards of the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that:
(1) All maximum wholesale petrol price increases sought or granted be refused or repealed.
(2) a single standard maximum wholesale petrol price for the whole of Australia (city and rural) be established and initially based on March 82 CPI quarter.
(3) Such a wholesale price be fixed for six months then adjusted in parity with pension/benefit increases twice yearly.

(4) Parity pricing to world oil prices be re-adjusted to 50 per cent of O.P.E.C . prices at the December 82 CPI quarter, and to be adjusted half-yearly to maintain 50 per cent relativity to world prices.
(5) parity pricing and oil prices be re-introduced into the CPI indexes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This humble petition of citizens of Australia showeth that:
Members of the Community are concerned and alarmed at the increasing levels of direct and indirect taxation.
Members of the community are concerned and alarmed at the increasingly inequitable distribution of these taxes through the Social Wage.
Members of the community are concerned and alarmed at the apparently uncontrolled increases in interest rates and the shrinking access to loan capital.
Members of the community are concerned and alarmed at the neglect of pension levels and the absence of real relativity with average wages.

Members of the community are concerned and alarmed at diminishing government spending on health, its consequential effect on the quality, cost and availability of Health Services and the absence of meaningful expenditure for the prevention of disease and injury.
We the undersigned citizens of Australia by this humble petition respectfully pray that the Australian Government introduce tax indexation on personal income tax scales and the tax free threshold.
Introduce:
(1) Broadly based wealth tax exempting small wealth holdings.
(2) Capital Gains tax exempting owner occupied homes.
(3) The closing of tax loopholes which enable company and high earner tax avoidance.
(4) A resources tax or excess profit tax.
The Australian Government raise the single pensions and benefits to 30 per cent of average weekly earnings over the next three years.

The Australian Government institute wide controls over interest rates charged by all lending institutions and pass legislation which will allow for a fixed percentage of all available loan capital to be held in reserve for the purpose of owner occupied home loans.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest the House have a general debate covering these Bills and the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1982 as they are associated measures. Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering these measures? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1 to 9) 1982 increase sales tax rates by 2 1/2 percentage points; that is, the three categories of sales tax rates are each increased by 2 1/2 percentage points. The lowest tax rate is increased from 5 per cent to 7 1/2 per cent; the intermediate rate, from 17 1/2 per cent to 20 per cent; and the top rate, from 30 per cent to 32 1/2 per cent. This is the second year in a row in which there have been significant increases in the rates of sales tax. Last year also sales tax rates increased by 2 1/2 percentage points, which means that the rate of tax on goods in the third Schedule, which incurs tax at the lowest rate, has gone up from 2 1 /2 per cent to 7 1/2 per cent in the last two Budgets covering a period of just one year. A trebling of rates in a year certainly is a very substantial rate of increase.

SPEECH.PARA: Goods covered in the lowest tax schedule which has had this enormous rate of increase in the rate of tax are principally household furniture and appliances and other household goods. Goods taxable at the intermediate rate have had their tax rate increased by one-third in the last two Budgets; that is, from 15 per cent to 20 per cent in the space of one year. These goods include cars, commercial vehicles, boats, computers, confectionery, stationery, soft drinks, spirits, beer and imported wine. The goods taxable at the top rate have had their tax increased by almost one-fifth in the space of one year; that is, over the last two Budgets. They include such items as radios, televisions, cameras, jewellery, cosmetics and so on.

The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill removes exemptions from a range of goods and imposes tax on them at 7 1/2 per cent. The goods not exempt, but which will now be taxed, include maps; hand tools, including gardening tools; motion picture films; household drapery and soft furnishings, including sheets and towels; servicing and construction equipment; cleaning cloths; and blankets. All those items were not previously subject to sales tax but are to be taxed at 7 1/2 per cent from 1 January next year. Some of those goods which are now to become taxable were included in the range of goods the Government sought to remove exemption from last year. The House will recall that in last year's Budget an attempt was made to raise $330m in a full year by taxing a whole array of items which were previously not taxable. The Government has not sought to reintroduce such an attempt to tax all those items again this year, but some of those items have been included in the list of goods which are now to be made taxable. Of course, last year the Government dropped its attempts to spread that tax to the wide variety of goods which had previously been exempt. This year it has picked up a number of items at which it was looking last year, including soft furnishings, drapery, manchester and hand tools.

These Bills amount to yet another move by the Government towards the introduction of a broadly based tax on goods and services. Over the last few years the Government has taken various measures to try to achieve this objective . In 1978 it set up an inquiry into such taxes as a broad-based tax on goods and services, which inquiry was soon abandoned following a major campaign by the Retail Traders Association. The Government set up another similar inquiry in 1980 following the 1980 election, which inquiry recommended an extended wholesale sales tax, which the Treasurer (Mr Howard) again rejected under political pressure by early 1981. In last year's Budget the Government extended the wholesale sales tax. The Treasurer denied that this was a move towards a more broadly based system and described it only as a small adjustment within the existing system.

Had all those intended changes in last year's Budget in respect of sales tax been passed the full-year revenue effect would have been a 32.7 per cent increase over the previous year's collections. It would have been a very substantial rate of increase in sales tax revenues indeed-hardly one, I would have thought, which befits the description of adjustment within the existing system. As I have previously mentioned, the attempts to obtain that substantial increase failed principally because the extension of tax to items previously exempt was abandoned eventually by the Government.

Finally, of course, the Government has announced further extensions in this year's Budget equivalent to a 20.8 per cent increase over last year's collections. So we have that substantial increase in sales tax revenue this year . Many new goods have been brought into the sales tax system by the correction of so-called anomalies and the extensions to previously exempt goods in this year's Budget. This is little more than a gradual move to a broader-based tax by the back door, which we can expect to see more of in future Budgets should this Government remain in office-which seems very doubtful.

These increases mean that sales tax collections have risen from 6 1/2 per cent of total Commonwealth tax collections in 1980-81 to 8.7 per cent this year, which is a very substantial leap in just two years. This has happened because of the very substantial sales tax measures which were announced in last year's Budget and in this year's Budget. As I have said, all this indicates attempts by the Government to introduce a broad-based indirect tax system in this country-a substantial move towards indirect taxes and less reliance perhaps on income tax. The Government may talk of less reliance on income tax but there has not been much evidence of that until this year's Budget and even now the tax cuts are small indeed.

The Opposition is not in favour of these measures but will not seek to prevent their passage by the Parliament. However, we wish to give formal expression to our concern at these measures. I therefore move the following amendment:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

'whilst not opposing the Bills the House expresses its concern at the Government's actions in again increasing sales taxes, which increases will have adverse consequences in regard to inflation, the equity of the tax system, and living standards'.

Let me amplify our reasons for concern at the imposition of these tax increases. As the amendment moved at the second reading stage states, we are concerned about the inflationary impact of what the Government is doing. There is no doubt whatever that these measures add to the rate of inflation. The Treasurer admitted that. He said in this House in March 1981 that a $500m increase in indirect taxes represents a one per cent increase in the consumer price index. He admitted quite clearly that substantial moves towards reliance on indirect taxes increases the rate of inflation and pushes up the consumer price index at that rate-one per cent for an increase of $500m. By virtue of the Bills now before us, the government is seeking to increase sales tax revenue this financial year by $414m and by $595m in a full year. The full year effect-the figure one should look at if one is concerned about prices-is over $500m. We can therefore say that the Treasurer, on the basis of his own calculations given to this House, is directly and indirectly adding something like one per cent or more to the consumer price index by increasing these sales tax rates and removing exemptions. That is clearly what he is doing.

This is a government which we are told fights inflation first, but last year and this year it sought to increase sales taxes in a way which clearly adds to inflation. The Government is fighting inflation by increasing prices. That is a very curious process indeed. This increase of one per cent from the increase in sales taxes in this Budget is not the end of the story. Other increases in indirect taxes in this Budget will certainly mean that in total the increase in the consumer price index, which comes from this move to increase indirect taxes, will be over 2 per cent. The total increase in direct taxes from measures announced in this Budget will be $1,046m this year but in a full year it will be $1,445m. That $1,445m, it can be seen, will add something near to 3 per cent to the consumer price index, on the basis that $500m equals one per cent.

This Budget is supposed to be concerned, as all previous Fraser Government Budgets were concerned, with fighting inflation, but it is quite clearly, on the face of the increases in revenue and the calculations given by the Treasurer, directly adding nearly 3 per cent to inflation by the increases in indirect taxes contained in it. That strikes us as quite an incredible process. Clearly it means a very significant boost to inflation. It is of course a major reason for spiralling unemployment. The rate of unemployment is now nearly 7 per cent. The Government admitted that in the very near future it will be over 8 per cent, and the Australian Financial Review claimed that by the end of this financial year it will be 10 per cent. Despite spiralling unemployment we still have a rate of inflation of the order of 11 per cent, on the Government's own calculations. Of course, a major reason why it is still of that order is that the Government is directly adding nearly 3 per cent to the rate of inflation by measures such as the one now before the House.

If the Government were concerned about getting the level of inflation down, one would think it would not add 3 per cent to the inflation rate by its own actions , but that is what it will do. By increasing these taxes it quite clearly not only directly increases the level of the CPI but also stimulates income claims by wage earners and others to make up for that increase in prices, and therefore adds indirectly to inflation. So we have quite a substantial inflationary impact stemming from such action. Both directly and indirectly there are inflationary impacts which in the end cause this very high level of inflation to continue despite massive unemployment. It strikes us as quite an incredible economic policy to pursue inflationary measures at a time when the Government continues to say that it is concerned to fight inflation. I must say that in the last year or two that rhetoric has tended to break down a little.

Last year's Budget raised indirect taxes almost wholly through sales tax rate increases by $449m in that financial year, and $596m in a full year. If we look at last year's Budget and this year's Budget we can say that in the space of a year-it is only just over a year ago since we discussed last year's Budget; indeed, we did so at this time last year-we had increases in indirect taxes of the order of $2 billion, or $2,041m to be exact. Again, on the basis of the Treasurer's own calculations, that adds about 4 per cent to the inflation rate in the space of a year. That is the kind of inflationary impact that we see from the Government's own actions. It is indeed a very large influence on the inflation rate. If it were not occurring we could be pretty sure-in fact, we could be absolutely certain-that there would be a much lower inflation rate than at present.

I wish to make one other point in respect of the inflationary effect of sales tax increases, and that is that the increase in prices which occurs because of sales tax increases is not only the amount of the sales tax increase. This wholesale sales tax is placed on the last wholesale price, but between the wholesale price and the retail price there is a substantial mark up. The mark up includes the wholesale price which incorporates the amount of sales tax. When one increases the level of sales tax, with constant mark ups, there is an automatic increase in the price as a result of not only the increase in the sales tax but also the 50 per cent mark up or whatever it is. A 50 per cent mark up and a 2 1/2 per cent increase in the price of, say, a refrigerator as a result of this Budget means that the sales tax increase will also be marked up. The increase in the price of that refrigerator will be 3.75 per cent. With a 7 1 /2 per cent tax applying to refrigerators, the actual increase in price caused by taxing refrigerators is not 7 1/2 per cent but 11 1/4 per cent, assuming a 50 per cent retail mark up. That is something to bear in mind when we look at these increases. It is not just a 2 1/2 per cent increase in the price; it is a 2 1/2 per cent increase in the wholesale price which, with constant markups, means that the retail price will go up at a higher level than that. The Budget has accelerated the inflationary impact in that way.

Another factor which causes us concern about these measures is the regressive nature of indirect taxes. As I have shown in earlier debates, increases in indirect taxes bear most heavily on lower income groups. Increases in indirect taxes are likely to reduce the equity of the tax system. It certainly is true that various international studies have looked at indirect taxes in many countries to ascertain where they fall and who is most affected by them. Some have argued that where broad based indirect taxes such as VAT-value added tax- apply the impact is near proportional, or at best proportional. I know of no one who argues that indirect taxes have a progressive effect in the way that income tax does if in fact the tax is not avoided by people on high incomes, as is certainly the case in this country at present. But certainly those international studies indicate that at best there is a proportional impact from indirect taxes and that most often the tax is regressive.

If that is the case in other countries we can certainly assume it to be the case here. Indeed, various studies have shown that that is the case here. I have alluded to those studies in previous debates in this House and I do not intend to refer to them now. We believe it is quite clear that the Australian indirect tax system is regressive. More reliance on that system means greater inequity in the tax system, or less equity, and that is a process which we deplore. In saying that I must take account of the fact that in this year's Budget the reductions in income tax that have been implemented-which cuts are in reality far less than the Government maintains after one takes account of the absence of tax indexation-are shaped in such a way that they do give greater benefits to lower income earners than to higher income earners, at least as regards the income tax scale. Items such as the mortgage interest tax deduction can be said to work in the opposite direction.

The countervailing increases in indirect taxes, much of which we are now discussing in the Bills before the House, will substantially, if not completely, offset the slight improvement in the equity of the tax system that comes from the revised income tax arrangements for this year. We do not see the tax system as having been improved in this Budget. Indeed, any benefits which have come from shaping the income tax cuts in a way which gives greater proportional benefits to people on lower incomes has been offset by the heavy additional increases in indirect taxes which are incorporated in the Budget.

Thirdly, dealing with the effect on living standards, the rise in sales taxes this year considerably reduces the improvement to living standards contained in other Budget measures. This financial year the average family will have its living standard reduced by $1.75 a week because of increased sales tax rates in the Budget. That figure comes from taking the total amount of revenue to be raised this year from sales tax increases and dividing that total by the number of Australian households. We get about $1.75 a week in additional sales tax payments per Australian household this financial year. With other increases in indirect taxes there will be an impact of about $4.40 a week on the living standards of Australian households. That is, they will pay on average $4.40 a week more in indirect taxes this year than they did last year as a result of the increases in the tax rates and the abolition of some exemptions which are contained in the Budget. That increase in sales tax more than counteracts the benefits from this year's Budget for many families, indeed for most of them, as I pointed out in my speech on the Budget. I do not intend to go back over them.

Furthermore, the increases in indirect taxes in the last two Budgets, in association with the increase in the income tax burden that has occurred in those two Budgets taken together, have more than wiped out the benefits to living standards from other measures in this year's Budget for almost all households. We can say that over the last two years there has not been a reduction in income tax. Indeed, there has been an increase in the income tax burden for Australian households. There has also been a significant increase in the indirect tax burden on Australian households, and those increases in the direct and indirect tax burden quite clearly and markedly outweigh any benefits contained in this year's Budget by way of increased family allowances or other benefits. We see Australian family living standards as having been adversely affected by the increases in indirect taxes in last year's Budget and in this one.

There is a fourth area of concern about the measures now before the House. We cannot accept the Government's arguments for implementing these increases. The Government argues, for two reasons, that it is desirable to place greater reliance on indirect taxes and less on income tax than is currently the case. Firstly, the Government says that we raise an unduly high proportion of our total tax revenue from income tax and therefore we should move more to indirect taxes. Secondly, it says that greater reliance on indirect taxes would enable us to reduce our losses through tax avoidance and tax evasion. Those are the two key arguments which this Government continually refers to as being reasons to move towards a broad based indirect tax system or more reliance on indirect taxes.

In regard to the first of those arguments, it is already the case that we raise a higher percentage of our taxes from indirect taxes than do countries generally in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. That is, on average we raise a higher proportion of our taxes from indirect taxes than do Western capitalist countries. The latest year for which we have comparable statistics is 1979. In that year Australia raised 31.71 per cent of its taxes from indirect taxes and the OECD average was 29.35 per cent. So in 1979 we were quite notably above the OECD average for the proportion of our taxes which we raised through indirect taxes. Since 1979 we have had big increases in the crude oil levy, and in the last two Budgets we have had big increases in sales taxes and other indirect taxes. We can assume, I think rightly, that that differential between us and the OECD would have increased over the three years since 1979. We believe that the argument that we need to move more towards indirect taxes because we have an undue reliance on income tax simply ignores the fact that Australia already has a relatively high proportion of its taxes raised through indirect taxes. The Government will simply not confront that argument.

The second argument which the Government uses is that more reliance on indirect taxes will help to reduce tax avoidance and tax evasion. I should like to make two points about that. It is just a straight cop-out to say that we cannot overcome the tax avoidance problem, therefore we will move more towards indirect taxes and make sure that those who are currently avoiding tax at least pay some tax through higher sales taxes. That is the kind of argument that is being used and it is one which we believe is totally and completely unacceptable. The duty of this Government is to make sure that people do not avoid income tax. Of course, as we have known from what has been discussed in this House in the last couple of weeks, and indeed over the last few years, this Government has been hopeless in preventing massive tax avoidance and evasion. Having come to the point almost of despair at its total inability to close off tax avoidance and evasion, or unwillingness to do anything about it, the Government says: 'Let us move more towards indirect taxes because at least in that way we will ensure that when people spend their money on various goods they will pay some taxes'. We believe that that is a complete cop-out of the Governments responsibilities. It is duty bound to ensure that it does everything in its power to prevent tax avoidance and evasion. I do not want to canvass the arguments in that regard now , but it is patently not doing that. It should be doing that if it wants to overcome the problem of tax avoidance, not use this cop-out approach and saying: 'Let us move towards indirect taxes so that the tax avoiders have to pay something when they buy a refrigerator, a blanket or whatever'.

The second reaction we have to the Government's argument is that it is simply not the case that indirect taxes are avoidance proof or anywhere near it. It is not the case overseas; it is not the case here. A report entitled 'Value Added Tax-a Study of its Practical Aspects' by J. D. Petty, a research paper for the Taxation Institute of Australian Research and Education Trust, is a study of indirect taxes overseas. It shows quite clearly that in country after country- the United Kingdom, France, the Netherlands, Denmark and Italy-there has been great trouble in preventing avoidance of value-added tax. Value-added tax is supposed to be the most secure, most self-enforcing, most avoidance proof of all the indirect taxes. Yet here we have a study which points to all sorts of problems that have been faced by governments overseas with the value-added tax. If one looks at the overseas experience one certainly cannot get any satisfaction about indirect taxes being avoidance proof, and therefore if we go more towards indirect taxes we will overcome the problems of tax avoidance. We simply will do that, on the basis of overseas experience. In regard to our own experience there is no reason to believe that that would be the case.

The Asprey Taxation Review Committee, which reported in 1975, indicated a variety of ways in which sales taxes could be easily avoided. Recent annual reports of the Commissioner of Taxation have indicated a considerable degree of detected avoidance and evasion of sales taxes. The latest annual report of the Taxation Commissioner says that 20,206 investigations were conducted during 1980 -81 resulting in additional tax and penalties of $20.6m. This is some evidence of avoidance and evasion. Also, the annual reports of the Taxation Commissioner show that the number of legal proceedings for enforcement of sales tax increased by 214 per cent between 1975-76 and 1979-80. In a very short period indeed we had a very substantial increase in the number of legal proceedings in this area. So, we can see that evidence shows that there is great difficulty in preventing avoidance of sales tax and indirect taxes.

But there has been also a lot of evidence recently about various new schemes which have been introduced in regard to avoidance of sales taxes. These take various forms. One form this avoidance takes is through price splitting which is used predominantly in the cosmetic, soft drink and pet food industries. Essentially, the price of a good is split into a manufacturing cost and a service cost with the service cost being funnelled through a subsidiary company set up for the purpose. The price claimed as the price of the product is taxable but the service charge is not. Cadbury Schweppes Pty Ltd is one company which has reportedly set up a service company in February of this year. It began double invoicing customers for, on the one hand, a service charge and, on the other hand, the cost of soft drinks. There have been various other evidences in the daily Press of this and other forms of schemes. As recently as yesterday there was an article in the Sydney Sun which was headlined 'Dealers In $250 mil Car Tax Fraud'. SPEECH.PARA: This year's Budget increases both expenditure and receipts. Part of the increase in receipts is from the sales tax measures which are the subject of this debate. Before I discuss them in detail I will deal with some of the broader issues. Clearly, in a time of world and Australian economic recession the type of Budget a government brings down must have different goals from a Budget presented in a relatively better economic climate. This Budget increases expenditure by 13.9 per cent and receipts by 11.3 per cent. That expenditure could well be increased further with the drought aid announcement made last week . That aid, of course, is meeting a specific need which has arisen in rural areas. Given the disastrous nature of the drought, its extent and its effects that aid was clearly called for, and I welcome the Government's initiative.

The point I make is that the increase in expenditure and the deficit is clearly aimed at stimulating the economy in this period of recession. I believe it is appropriate and defensible on those grounds. I say that because I am a strong believer in smaller government rather than larger government. I adhere to the view that we ought to be pressing to reduce the size of government. However, to adopt rigidly that line of argument while ignoring the recession and the appropriate remedy for our current economic ills would be unrealistically intransigent.

It will be well known that during the 1930s recession governments generally undertook a great deal of belt-tightening which many believed aggravated the problems of that period. Having learned our lesson most economists agree that it is better now to try to mildly stimulate economic activities in times such as this, which, of course, is one of the objectives of this Budget. Australia is not only confronted with a world recession but also the recession comes at a time when, as a result of excessive wage demands, we have seriously disadvantaged ourselves because we have lost a great deal of our competitive advantage on world markets. It is, therefore, essential that our wages structure be brought into line with the rest of the world. This Budget provides enormous assistance through reductions in taxation and an increase in benefits to all Australians. The benefits especially for the average family are worth around $20 a week. Even if we deduct the cost of the increases on sales taxes imposed by these Bills it is well recognised that the average family will still be around $ 17 a week better off.

The Government has taken the initiative to increase take-home pay. That initiative must be taken into consideration when wage increases are being sought . It is in this context that I repeat: Our wage structure must be brought into line with the rest of the world. I am, therefore, disgusted when I see that, despite the Government's action and despite the high level of unemployment in Australia, the Australian Council of Trade Unions appears to remain intent on entrenching excessive levels of wages growth. I quote the Acting Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, the present Minister for Communications (Mr N.A. Brown), who said on 3 September:
The ACTU's wages strategy, if put into effect, would mean a substantial further increase in real earnings over 1982-83, a further squeeze on profits and a marked deterioration in employment.
He went on:

This strategy involves a specific campaign of industrial action in sensitive industries in order to force employers to concede. The unions seem unwilling to bring their claims to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission where they can be examined on their merits with regard to the public interest, free of disruptive industrial action.
If Australia is to progress out of this recession there must be co-operation from the unions, otherwise there will be higher unemployment and lower standards of living.

I turn now to the details of these Bills. The Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1 to 9) impose an increase on the various rates of sales tax of 2 1/2 percentage. In other words, the respective rates will increase from 5 per cent to 7 1/2 per cent, from 17 1/2 per cent to 20 per cent and from 30 per cent to 32 1/2 per cent. The result is an increase in revenue this year of $370m and, in a full year, an increase of $490m. The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill imposes sales taxes of 7 1/2 per cent on a range of goods that were previously exempt. Those goods range from mats, hand tools and to equipment used in the course of servicing, repair or construction. It does not include goods which become part of the goods being repaired or the structure being built . The Bill will increase revenue by $44m this year and $105m in a full year. The total estimated revenue from these changes this year will be $414m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ripping off the poor.

—In a full year this will amount to $595m. It is interesting to hear the interjection: 'Ripping off the poor'.
