Honourable members will see from the figures that the interjection is totally false. The Opposition seems blind to the real economic effects of this Budget. There are changes in the income tax rates scale and I will outline them: There is a reduction in the standard rate of tax from 32c down to 30c in the dollar; there is an increase in the tax free threshold from $4,195 to $4,595; and the standard rate step of tax will rise from $17,894 to $19,500. The cost for this year will be $1,468m. Let us compare that with the $414m increase in revenue from the sales tax measures, the subject of these Bills. It is quite clear that the thrust of the Budget is to increase take home pay. The interjections are totally false. The full year cost of the income tax reductions is $2,357m. Compare that with $595m, the full year cost of the sales tax measures, the subject of these Bills. There is no doubt that those figures support the view that families will be better off as a result of this Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: However, there is a further and important matter to be considered when discussing these Bills. They are a step in the right direction in correcting an imbalance in our reliance on income tax as a source of revenue. I will refer to the table which I referred to earlier in this debate, which is an annexure to the Treasurer's statement last year. One can see that 20 years ago, in 1962-63, the proportion of the Commonwealth Government's revenue raised from personal income tax was around 37 per cent. This year it is around 55 per cent. In other words, over the last 20 years there has been a steady growth in the proportion of revenue coming from income tax. I believe it is imperative to redress this situation because high levels of income tax are a disincentive for individuals. It is a disincentive to invest and a disincentive for individuals to increase their work effort or to do overtime. These are fundamental reasons why there are obvious advantages in changing the mix of direct and indirect taxation. Clearly, if we are to shift our emphasis of revenue raising away from direct taxation it will increase the prospect of further substantial and desirable reductions in direct tax, particularly personal income tax.

These Bills are effective in reducing the amount that would otherwise have to be raised by income tax not only by increasing sales tax on some items that are already taxed but also by broadening the base of goods which are to be subject to sales tax. In fact, this year, the proportion of revenue raised by income tax will remain high even though there is an increase in sales tax. This year it is estimated that personal income tax will raise 55.8 per cent of the Commonwealth Budget's taxation revenues. Company tax will raise 12.6 per cent. It is worth looking at that figure because last year the proportion of the Budget raised from company tax was 13.9 per cent. The year before it was 15 per cent. Why the proportion of company tax has dropped is pretty clear. The rate of profitability of our companies in Australia has fallen because there has been an unbelievable wage push in Australia.

The proportion of revenue raised from customs, excise and sales tax will increase this year from 20.8 per cent to 22.2 per cent of total taxation revenues. The proportion of revenue arising from the crude oil levy will fall from 8.4 per cent last year to 7.4 per cent this year. So overall the proportion of revenue arising from personal income tax will fall by less than one per cent. One reason is that the amounts raised from company tax and the crude oil levy will fall. The proportion of tax arising from the customs, excise and sales tax measures will increase and the proportion arising from personal income tax will remain about the same. However, I reiterate that, given economic recovery and increased company profitability, there is the prospect that revenue from company tax will rise and further reductions in personal tax could be a prospect.

I want to mention briefly two other points. If we continue to shift the burden from direct tax to indirect tax this will mean that those who buy goods for resale, which are subject to the tax, will have to find larger amounts of money to fund the purchases of those goods for the period they remain unsold. At the moment sales tax is payable 21 days after the month in which the goods were purchased by the person intending to resell them. Therefore, if we are to continue to go down the track of moving from direct to indirect taxation the Government will have to give consideration to the time which is given to pay these taxes. At the moment 21 days is allowed. It may well be that to ease the burden on the cash flow, particularly that of small businesses, that period ought to be reviewed to see if more time to pay should be given in the future.

The other matter I want to raise is the confusion which inevitably follows the announcements on Budget night of increases in sales tax. There was an example again this year of consumers going into shops and small businessmen not knowing whether to impose the new sales tax. There is a clear distinction between excise and sales tax. Some excises are imposed from the night of the Budget, but sales taxes are imposed on goods which are subsequently bought by the retailer. It is, therefore, not correct for the retailer to impose those sales taxes unless they are in respect of goods which are bought by the retailer following the Budget.

I believe the Commissioner of Taxation ought to make available an explanation of the difference between the excise and sales tax increases which inevitably occur in budgets. If such an explanation is readily available to small businessmen I think it would be of benefit to them and when changes occur after a Budget they would know whether they had to increase the prices of their goods. That will avoid the problem which arose in Adelaide this year when some businessmen put up the price because they did not know. Customers were aggrieved -reasonably and fairly so-by that. They took the matter up, I understand, with the office of consumer affairs in South Australia. If the Commissioner of Taxation could make the above mentioned information available I think it would assist the small businessman. I conclude by wholeheartedly supporting these Bills as part of what I believe is a very welcome Government Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: Both the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1 to 9) and the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill represent a continuing assault by this Government on the living costs and living standards of Australian families. The Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1 to 9) have the effect of increasing by 2 1/2 percentage points all those increased rates which applied from last year anyway and the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1982 has the effect of bringing into the sales tax net a number of goods that had previously escaped it. There is no question that the Government is quite determined to continue this assault. It was thwarted last year in the miserable attempt that it made to inflict a 2 1/2 per cent sales tax on what were classified as the necessities of life, for example, kids' clothing and shoes, building materials for people's homes, and books and newspapers. Fortunately that was rejected by the Senate and the Government has not had the gall to reintroduce it-at least not on this occasion.

This whole Budget package was introduced in the context of an early election. If that election takes place there will be a reversal in approach and the Government will introduce all these fiscal measures next year. The Government knows that, we know it and the Australian community knows it as well. Despite all the Government's rhetoric about adjusting the tax mix, the fact remains that indirect taxes are regressive, unjust, inequitable and create a much more severe burden on lower income earners. The approach that this Government has taken to this question throws into very serious doubt any suggestion that this Government might be humane or might have any compassionate feelings for those people in the community whom it continues to burden.

The repeated claim by both the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Treasurer in relation to indirect taxes is that there is some need to adjust the tax mix, to place more emphasis on indirect taxes, to provide scope for a reduction in personal income tax. In fact what is their real objective? I think this was indicated very clearly in a radio interview with the Prime Minister in Perth in December last year. He said:
Also I think the best way to spread the burden a bit is to have a broader-based indirect tax--
I emphasise the next group of words:
. . . because that does raise quite a lot of money.

Indeed it does. It is raised from people who should not be expected to make the contribution of that big amount of money. I will quote from the editorial of the Newcastle Herald of 1 September last year relating to the consideration given to sales tax intentions at that time. The following are not my words but are from a responsible, reputable and highly respected major provincial newspaper in Australia. The editorial stated:
Nothing the Government says on taxation can be accepted with anything but scepticism.

What the article went on to state is in marked contrast with the sort of nonsense we get from honourable members on the Government side, including the Treasurer, who should be here when the Budget is being considered rather than flying around the world. He should be here not only to answer the charges about the Costigan and McCabe-Lafranchi reports but also to defend his Budget. The Newcastle Herald continued:
The regrettable aspect of the political juggling is that sales tax is here to stay.
The editorial further stated:
It is a vicious tax, and in some respects even an undemocratic one.

Of course it is. There is no way in which the Opposition will support the continuous shift towards indirect taxes. Of course, the Treasurer repeated the claim when introducing these amendment Bills this year. He said:
I drew attention last year to the clear advantage that lies in effecting some change in the mix of direct and indirect taxes.
He further stated:
I again emphasise the potential that such a change generates for desirable reductions in direct taxes, particularly personal income tax.

Of course, the Government was taking advantage of the situation before what it thought was going to be a snap election to introduce these measures. The more obvious measures appear to have some sort of concessional arrangement built into them. Obviously the Treasurer has learnt the way in which it is possible to finance tax cuts that he was wondering about in April this year. He said: 'Tax cuts are not feasible. Where are we going to find the money?' He has discovered the solution: To provide tax cuts with the one hand you must drag the money back with the other. Of course, that is what these sales tax increases are intended to do.

The Sales Tax Amendment Bills are designed to impose a sales tax of 7.5 per cent in a range of goods that are now exempt from the sales tax under the First Schedule. Let us look at some of the things that will impact on households. There will be a 7 1/2 per cent sales tax on cleaning and polishing cloths, cleaning sponges, handkerchiefs, blankets, braid, ribbon and tape, household drapery and soft furnishings. Some of the goods taxed that will have an impact on industry are contained in the first list but as well as those are hand tools, engine cleaning cotton waste, and servicing and construction equipment. Of course, last year the Government wanted to impose a 2 1/2 per cent tax on building materials but it was not allowed to get away with it. This year the Government has decided to compensate in some way-it still wants to make sure that the home builders are ripped off-by building into the cost of home construction in Australia a 7 1/2 per cent sales tax on equipment used to build homes. That particular provision is to give a net result to revenue this year of $44m and $105m over a full year.

The next provision is even more interesting and fascinating. Let us look at some of the provisions of the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1 to 9) for this year. First of all, the 5 per cent sales tax rate will be increased to 7.5 per cent. I do not think we should allow the claim to continue to be made that the increase is 2.5 per cent. In fact, it is not; it is an increase of 2.5 percentage points and the increase in the sales tax is 50 per cent. In two years the sales tax paid on those items included in the Third Schedule has increased by 200 per cent. The increase in sales tax on items in the Fourth and Fifth Schedules and those goods that were not covered by any Schedules has been from17 .5 per cent to 20 per cent. It was suggested again that that is an increase of 2 .5 per cent. In fact, the increase is 14.3 per cent and it should be recognised as such. The sales tax levied on items in the Second Schedule has increased from 30 per cent to 32.5 per cent. Again, it has been suggested that the increase is 2.5 per cent. It is nothing of the kind; it is 8.3 per cent.

Let us look at the fascinating contrast between the 8.3 per cent increase in sales tax and the other increases. The percentage increase of 8.3 per cent will apply to things such as jewellery and furs, gold plated wear, perfumery and bath salts. I will now tell honourable members some of the things on which sales tax will increase by 14.3 per cent. They do not include the bath salts of the wealthy but the soap of the lower and middle income earners, kids' bicycles, soap powders, disinfectants, soft drinks, toilet paper and kids' toys. The percentage increase in sales tax on those items is 14.3 per cent but the percentage increase on the bath salts of the wealthy, the gold plated wear, the perfumery and the jewellery and furs of the wealthy is 8.3 per cent. The increase of 50 per cent goes on refrigerators, washing machines and a range of household goods. So the people who are struggling to get their homes together will pay an increase in sales tax of 50 per cent. What a miserable approach. Is there anyone on the Government side who can reasonably defend such a proposition ? The increases will give a net result this year of $370m and the rip-off over a full year will be another $490m.

Let me give the total increases in this Government's Budget from indirect taxes . The increase in the existing rate of 2.5 percentage points, not 2.5 per cent, will yield $490m in a full year. The application of sales tax at a rate of 7.5 per cent to goods in the First Schedule will yield $105m a year. The excise on distillate for off-road use will yield $176m a year. The increased excise on beer will yield $135m a year. The increased excise on cigarettes and tobacco will yield $125m a year. The total increase will be $1,031m a year. We can add to that the commensurate increases on Customs and excise duty, the tax on bank transactions and other indirect taxes yielding $200m in a full year. We can add the increase that is expected on the excise duty on oil and liquified petroleum gas this year which will be another $220m. So the increases continue.

I will finish on this point: In 1975-76 the proportion of total taxation which was provided by indirect taxes was 28 per cent. That was at the end of the period of the last Labor Government. That Government had been able to reduce the proportion because it did not believe that indirect taxes should be raising the revenue. Now the proportion is back up to 30 per cent. There is no question that if the Australian people want equity built into the tax system and the way in which the Australian community is managed there is only one party in Australia that is determined to and capable of building equity into the system and that is the Australian Labor Party. The Australian people will have the opportunity to establish that change very shortly.

The first study I refer to was carried out by the Committee for Economic Development of Australia and is titled 'The Reform of the Commonwealth Government Sales Tax' and is dated August 1982. On page 10 of that report, under the heading 'Equity', it states:

In assessing the equity of a tax it is useful to distinguish between horizontal and vertical equity. To satisfy horizontal equity, a tax should impose the same burdens on individuals having an equal capacity to pay tax. Vertical equity requires that individuals with unequal capacity to pay be treated differently and in accordance with that inequality.

Vertical equity considerations suggest that a tax should be proportional or progressive with respect to income. Hence there is concern about the regressive nature of a broad-based indirect tax. Although essentially proportional in terms of consumption expenditure, the tax is regressive as related to income. This is because the proportion of income spent on consumption goods declines with movement up the income scale. The question then arises as to whether any regressivity introduced by the proposed changes should be compensated by income tax or social welfare adjustment.

It is obvious that the tax cuts afforded the community offer only an indexation catch-up and in no way compensate for the massive increases in indirect taxes. The next study I refer to is the 1975 report of the Taxation Review Committee, under the chairmanship of Mr Justice Asprey. It showed quite clearly that taxation is very sharply regressive at the lower end of the household income scale, nearly proportional in a wide middle band, and progressive only at higher levels. The reason given was that indirect taxes are chiefly responsible for this occurrence. These include maps, hand tools, soft furnishings and servicing, repair and construction equipment. The tax on servicing, repairing and reconditioning equipment for motor vehicles, aeroplanes, ships and railway rolling stock will inevitably force up transport costs within my electorate and indeed throughout the whole nation.

Pet food is now subject to a 20 per cent duty. This must seriously affect the commercial exploitation of kangaroos. It is just another example of this Government's concern for country jobs. This issue was taken up by a Liberal Party member for Lower North in the Western Australian Upper House who was lamenting the Government's decision to tax the industry so savagely.

This year, as a result of the Budget, we find that a special surcharge on motor spirit and distillate is to be introduced. This must raise between $300m and $ 400m in a full year when the 2c a litre surcharge is reached. The only redeeming feature of the surcharge is that it will be set aside in a special trust account for road works. My electors will want to see some appreciable road works before they cop this. I have always held the opinion that sufficient funds are derived from existing crude oil and liquefied petroleum gas excise duties to cover an impressive road construction program. I note that this year the oil levy is up 3 .9 per cent and will bring $3,287m into Government coffers. I cannot support this double tax on the motorist just simply in the name of road works. A portion of the existing crude oil levy should be set aside for road works.

The Budget envisages lifting the exemption from excise duty for off-road diesel fuel. This is designed to yield $176m in a full year. This new duty will adversely affect agriculture and the fishing and mining industries in my electorate. It must lead to higher transport and power charges. Bricks and road building materials will cost more, so will fuel for cranes, tractors, bulldozers , excavation equipment, on-site power generators, and other diesel-fired machinery. Once again, the country suffers more than the city. The Government is intent on gaining an extra $12.5m from increased air navigation charges. This will inevitably make it more expensive to travel within Western Australia and interstate. Air fares are already very high. It currently costs $90 to fly from Kalgoorlie to Perth. It costs $174.20 to fly from Port Hedland to Perth and $291 .50 from Kununurra to Perth. Since I got those figures a few days ago there has been a substantial increase in fares of the order of 7 per cent. The Government should be moving to check air fare price rises, not fuelling the fires. The very least it can do is to allow Trans Australia Airlines to compete on some of the lucrative interstate routes.

I now turn my attention to some of the Budget outlays. Despite their much heralded announcement, many Budget allocations are paltry. Under Prime Minister Fraser unemployment is a growth industry. How does he treat the unemployed? Unemployment and sickness benefits for young people under 18 years of age will rise by only $4 a week from $36 to $40-the first increase since 1978-and by only $6.30 from $58.10 to $64.40 for people over 18 years of age. The Government will no doubt expect these beneficiaries to live gratefully on the smell of an oily rag for another four years. Once again, pensioners received a pittance, with a $ 3.10 a week increase for single pensioners and a $5.20 a week increase for couples. No attempt has been made to index pensions realistically. It is commendable that the limit on permissible pensioner earnings has been increased, albeit for the first time in 10 years. I just wonder how many pensioners will be able to earn the extra income, given the current state of the economy. The easing of the income test requirement for the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme and Secondary Allowances Scheme is welcome. This will not, however, significantly ease the burden for parents in the north of Western Australia, where wages and costs tend to be high. I welcome the increase in funds for assistance programs for young unemployed. I regret that no significant plan for job expansion is contained in this Budget.

In the time I have left I wish to say a little about the Liberal Party philosophy which underlies this Budget. Insofar as any economic theory has controlled the Fraser Government's economic policy, it has been based on these nostrums: Firstly, inflation is caused by deficits; secondly, if deficits fall inflation falls; thirdly, higher economic growth and a rising inflation rate are mutually exclusive; fourthly, a rising inflation rate makes people save a greater proportion of their income and therefore suppresses aggregate demand and growth; and fifthly, interest rate increases are caused by public sector borrowing demand and interest rates will fall if public sector borrowing demand falls. The great bulk of Australian statistical evidence contradicts all these beliefs. This now is becoming generally known by a long suffering public. The last and most damaging piece of Fraser-Treasury dogma that prices and incomes policies never work--

SPEECH.PARA: Two salient points came through to me in this Budget. Secondly-the honourable member for Kalgoorlie did admit this, I acknowledge that-it is a family Budget. If honourable members do an analysis on the figures they will see that the Budget is in fact far from being a confidence trick. An average Australian who is earning $300 a week will be up to $17 a week better off than he was previously as a result of the Budget, even taking into account the higher sales tax and other charges that were introduced. In this Budget the total benefits available to an average family consisting of a sole breadwinner with a wife and two children paying off a $25, 000 mortgage on their home, amount to $19.84 a week. However, the indirect tax increases admittedly can raise this family's weekly expenditure by about $3 a week. The largest single component of the increase was $6.69 in reduced tax rates, while the home loan increase rebate accounts for $5.05. That is real relief for one section of our community that has certainly suffered most severely.

If we are serious about making an effort to support the family unit and the concept of the family unit in Australian society, certainly this Budget goes a long way towards doing just that. The other overall Budget expenditures are interesting too. Defence spending, for example, is up by 11.8 per cent; education expenditure is up by 13.5 per cent; health expenditure is up by 16 per cent and housing expenditure is up by 24 per cent. TALK.START.PARA: —Adelaide International Airport.

SPEECH.PARA: Major works also are being undertaken at Cairns, Townsville, Coolangatta, Maroochydore, Bundaberg and, of course, the secondary airport for Brisbane at Archerfield. In fact, there are major projects right around Australia as Australia upgrades its facilities to take part in this tremendous boom in international tourism to Australia. I am sure that with the additional works being done at Adelaide Airport, with Perth Airport being upgraded and the upgrading of other secondary airports around Australia there is this realisation that the tourist industry has a great deal to offer. It is interesting to see the pattern of employment that is developing in Australia. Once again I will cite the situation that exists in Queensland. In fact, at the moment Queensland enjoys the lowest rate of unemployment in Australia and, indeed, the lowest rate of youth unemployment in Australia. I think we should always be careful to analyse just what is happening in this area. There is some reason for concern about what is happening in Queensland. There will be 25,000 young people going on to the job market in that State this year. These are people who come from the State of Queensland. In addition, it is now estimated that 9,000 school leavers from New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia and their families will be migrating to Queensland during the Christmas period and will be looking for work.

If we look at the figures showing what has happened in recent years I suppose we can get an indication of just how serious the problem could become. In the last five years there has been a doubling of the number of New Zealanders coming to settle in Australia. The number of New Zealanders permanently living in Australia at the moment is in excess of 180,000. In the past we have always had something of a balance between the number of New Zealanders coming here, gaining employment and settling and the number of Australians going to New Zealand.

At the moment there are around 55,000 Australians living on a permanent basis in New Zealand but the number of New Zealanders here, in excess of 180,000, gives some sort of indication of the imbalance. I wonder just how long that situation can go on. I will cite as an example a situation that has developed in my electorate. I think the two critical electorates in the Queensland situation are the electorates of McPherson and Bowman which lie respectively on the Gold Coast and on the shores of Moreton Bay. In the bayside suburb of Wynnum, where there is some light manufacturing industry, an example came to light in recent days. One of the major clothing manufacturing companies there, one that is doing very well and which has had a major expansion in recent years, has been employing extra staff. Forty jobs were going in recent weeks. Applications were called. Jobs were advertised. Commonwealth employment officers were notified. In actual fact the person who runs that factory employed 32 New Zealanders as part of that intake of 40 people. He tells me he did not particularly want to do that ; he wanted to provide jobs for Australians but the Australians did not apply. He said that from talking to the 32 people that he put on it would seem that usually New Zealanders tend to find jobs in Brisbane within three days or four days of their arrival.

One wonders just what is wrong with the employment situation in that south-east corner of Queensland if we cannot get some of our unemployment figures down and some of those Australians who are looking for work into the work force. They are really quite remarkable figures. I believe that the whole area of New Zealand migration to Australia will have to be looked at very closely indeed. Of course, we realise that it is not only Queensland that is experiencing this tremdous influx of New Zealanders but other States of Australia too.

It is good to know that the Government has acknowledged some of these difficulties and is prepared to go ahead and provide that sort of relief to the people of my electorate by continuing to complete that airport project.

Another area of the Budget which has raised quite a deal of comment in Queensland is foreign aid. Unfortunately, some rather prominent groups and personalities in Queensland say that perhaps Australia is spending too much on aid and we should be looking after our own first rather than developing some of the international aid projects. Whilst not coming into that argument, I was particularly perturbed at outbursts in the Press in Brisbane about the $10m that is being promised to the people who have been suffering in the Lebanon as a result of the war that has been continuing there since the early 1970s. In fact, the $10m that has been allocated I believe is a generous donation which will be used for humanitarian purposes. One can only support the Government in giving that aid and urge the people of Australia to give as much as they possibly can to help relieve the suffering that is happening at the moment in the Lebanon.

One would hope that following the withdrawal of the Palestine Liberation Organisation and the election of a new President, Mr Beshir Gemayel, who takes up his new position in the next few weeks, at last the people of that strife torn country will be able to receive some sort of peace. They have not been able to enjoy any sort of existence there for the last 12 years. It was a war in which the Lebanese themselves were not involved. It was a war which a number of Arab factions from that part of the world decided that they would fight on Lebanese territory. It was amazing to know that in fact the PLO seemed to be fighting a number of factions, the Iraquis and the Iranians were fighting their own particular war and the PLO and the Kuwaitis were having exchanges from time to time with the people of Beirut, especially West Beirut, being virtually caught in the cross-fire. Nobody is denying that the new President of the Lebanon, Beshir Gemayel, has a very hard task in trying to restore some semblance of order to that strife torn land. We can only wish him the best and hope that in some way there can be a sense of national reconciliation in that country.

Lebanon is one of the oldest civilizations in the world. It is a country that has recognised human rights for hundreds of years. It is a country in which people of different religions and persuasions have managed to live side by side in peace and harmony for the last 400 years. It was sad to see the dominance of human rights being torn apart by a war that was not of the making of the Lebanese people. We can only shudder in horror at the thought that elements in the Australian society would deny any aid we can give to that strife torn country. One would hope that the appeals for genuine welfare aid that are undertaken by the Lebanese community itself and the Red Cross organisation will be well supported. Of course, the Government has already acknowledged that donations to those campaigns will be tax deductible.

Once again, and in conclusion, let me say that I thought the most significant things in this Budget were the recognition of the very great difficulties facing the families of this nation, the recognition that tax relief was needed-tax relief was given-and the recognition that high interest rates were affecting many young families. Tax deductibility for interest on home loans over and above 10 per cent will provide very real relief for the people who need it most. There was also a recognition that very great consideration must be given to the aged and the underprivileged in our society, and that was given. To a great extent the Budget was a humane Budget. It is one that should be welcomed by all the Australian community. It showed real compassion, while in very hard circumstances it gave room for people to make their own way in Australia once again and for Australia to take advantage of the world situation once it comes out of the recession that is causing havoc world wide.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Government and its Cabinet are undoubtedly the most incompetent, arrogant, divisive and hypocritical in Australia's history. The Government's incompetence is matched only by its hypocrisy and arrogance. It has introduced a no-hope Budget masquerading as a welfare Budget. But its welfare aspects are long overdue. In most cases the welfare elements are inadequate. They involve simply the indexation of benefits, pension thresholds and tax scales that should have been introduced long ago. The question is: When is a tax cut not a tax cut? The answer is, firstly, when it has elements of simple application of the consumer price index for 1981-82 to the existing tax scales and, secondly, when the total of increases in sales tax and excise duty more than equals the cut of 2c in the dollar in the basic tax scale. All that has happened is that the 10.4 per cent CPI rise for 1981-82 has been applied to the first two tax scales, which lifted the threshold of the first scale by $400 to $4,595 and that of the second scale by $1,606 to $19,500. So that is only a simple application of the 10.4 per cent consumer price index rise for 1981-82. The cut of 2c in the dollar in the basic tax rate is the only real tax cut in the Budget but that is more than offset by increases in sales tax and excise duty. The cut of 2c in the dollar on the lower tax scale means a loss to revenue of $706m this financial year and $1,066m in a full year. That is almost precisely equal to the increase in income resulting from increases in sales tax and excise duty, which amount to $786m in this financial year and over $1 billion in a full year.

SPEECH.PARA: The increase of 50 per cent to the income test threshold for age pensions is welcome but it is long overdue, simply being a recognition that no adjustment, at all had taken place since 1972. There is still no real increase, apart from the CPI adjustment, to base pensions. The unemployment benefit for single people is still well below the poverty line. However, behind the belated concessions that I have mentioned, if one reads the fine print of the Budget one will find a picture of unmitigated gloom. For example, the Budget Papers say that we can expect no real growth in non-farm output for 1982-83. Unemployment over the last financial year had risen by 100,000 to 460,500 as at 30 June last. The consumer price index rose in the last four years from 8.2 per cent in 1978-79 to 10.4 per cent in 1981-82. So after four years of this Government's vicious throttling of the economy the only result has been that unemployment has risen by 100,000 and the consumer price index has risen by 2.2 per cent. The balance of payments position is a complete trauma and disaster; the current account is $9 billion in deficit; and private capital inflow, on which the Government relies to balance its balance of payments books, is at a record $10.2 billion. The Treasury sees no hope of improvement. So despite seven long years of vicious attack on the Australian economy, what have we to show? We have increasing inflation over the past four years, no growth, exploding unemployment, record interest rates and an ever-deteriorating balance of payments.

Despite all this no hope, doom and gloom, in the fine print of the Budget, the Government still hoped to sell it as pre-election Budget. It was going to make one last desperate gambler's throw for three more years in office before the voters woke up-woke up to the fact that Australia is in deep recession, on the brink of depression. Of course, all that has now been frustrated by the astounding disclosures and incredible exposures of incompetence, irresponsibility and economic and legal mismanagement that Mr Costigan exposed in his report. We now see the incompetence in the Treasury, the Taxation Office and the Attorney-General's Department and a complete inability to combat the tax cheats. They have been able to pursue small, individual pay-as-you-earn income earners to the point of dragging working class pay-as-you-earn individuals before the courts, but they have gone in lightly on the big company crooks and on their crooked mates in the Liberal Party.

What has been the result? The result has been a loss to revenue over the past few years of $7 billion to $10 billion. Had that money been collected, every pay -as-you-earn taxpayer in Australia could now receive a $1,000 rebate cash in hand, which would not be a bad boost to the economy. Had this Government and the Attorney-General's Department, as requested by the Taxation Office, prosecuted as recommended by Brinsden J. back in 1975, these schemes would have been arrested. There would have been no need for the Government to renege on its promise to implement full tax indexation. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the Attorney- General (Senator Durack) say that they are not responsible and the people of Australia are supposed to be satisfied with the prosecution of three minor officials in Perth. What about the Ministers who have let this enormous loss to the revenue take place, and what about the person who was the Crown Solicitor in those years and who is now head of the Attorney-General's Department? What is the Government going to do about it? It will take no action at all against those Ministers and bureaucrats who are responsible.

I ask the House to contrast this sick record of economic failure, ministerial irresponsibility and incompetence with Labor's plans and policies for when it reaches the government benches opposite. That will not be before very long, I assure the House, because we are willing to fight an election, if the Government is game, at any time it likes. Our plans and policies include a return to centralised wage indexation, which will not only control unnecessary wage increases to very high income earners but also give justice to the one and a half million people who have not received any wage increase due to the Government's destruction of wage indexation early last year. We will go for real income tax reform-not fairy floss income tax reform, and a real crackdown on the tax rorts-and a fair system of financing State and local government through revenue sharing, through a return to the system of block and tied grants to finance essential social services such as health services, through a new consultative approach to Loan Council borrowing programs with the States and through the guarantee of total funds to the States. We will introduce a new health insurance scheme under which people and families will be asked to pay only 0.75 per cent of their taxable income instead of up to $16 a week which they pay now and which many families cannot afford under this Government. There will be new housing policies in contrast to the hopeless record of this Government in that area. I believe housing, after unemployment, is probably our biggest social problem, and this Government must take full responsibility for record interest rates, record rents and the collapse of public housing construction in Australia. The dimensions of the problem are enormous. I know that over 100,000 people are on the waiting lists of the State housing commissions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Families.

—Families, I stand corrected by the honourable member for Reid, our shadow Minister for housing. Three times that number are in very poor accommodation, and we need at least 45,000 more starts a year than we are getting at present under this Government. Eighty per cent of new home seekers in this country cannot even get near raising loans at the minimum interest rate of 13.5 per cent that is required by the Commonwealth Savings Bank at the moment. Interest rates, as I said before-one cannot say it often enough-have gone up 4 per cent in two years. That means that someone paying off a modest little loan on a modest little house in an outer suburb of one of our great urban centres is paying $90 a month more than was the case two years ago. If this Government proceeds, as I am sure it will, into a deregulated Campbell situation we can expect an incredible increase of a further 3 per cent in interest rates, which will mean that such people will be paying another $70 a month on top of the $90 extra a month they are paying already.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government presides over a high interest rate regime. Its Budget scheme recognised that the March home loan amelioration scheme was not sufficient. It recognised that only 28 per cent of people in the housing loan market obtained relief. Now the Government has introduced a scheme of giving a rebate of 30c in the dollar on all interest paid over 10 per cent on loans up to $60,000. But there is no ceiling on the interest rate that is to be paid and no ceiling on the size of the actual loan. This can push people into fringe banking organisations and encourage them to take higher interest rate loans. Only 10 per cent of home owners or seekers now are involved in this sort of finance. This scheme will encourage more and more of them into it, while it will do nothing at all for those who cannot even get a loan in the first place or who may be renting accommodation.

The private sector in the housing area needs a number of policy applications, the first, of course, being to hold and then to reduce interest rates. But then it needs special measures to attract funds for housing finance, and certainly it needs an improvement to the existing deposit assistance scheme that this Government has implemented. In the public sector this is the greatest disgrace of all because, in 1982-83 prices, only $318m goes to the State housing commissions this year compared with, in 1982-83 prices, over $900m in the 1975- 76 financial year. A substantial increase is required in this area.

I turn now to some environmental issues. The Government has maintained its low priority for environmental matters. This Budget is a 'do the minimum possible' Budget to match the Government's 'leave it to the States' policy. The manufacture, use, transport and disposal of hazardous chemicals is a major problem, yet for the third year in a row the Department of Home Affairs and Environment used 60 per cent of its meagre $40,000 allocation for hazardous chemicals. This year a staff of four will have to run a voluntary interim notification scheme for new chemicals-that is, less than one-third the number deemed necessary by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation. I see that time is beating me, but as I wish to make some comments about the disastrous state of the steel industry I will have to cut short my remarks on environmental issues and return to them at a later date. However, I make the point that, despite this Government's alleged concern for the environment, only $19m, representing an increase of just 3 per cent, is to be spent on environmental matters this year.

I said that housing and unemployment were the great social problems of our times and that unemployment is a particular blight, especially for young people. It is stated in the Budget that the level of unemployment is now about 7 per cent and is expected to rise to 8 per cent in this financial year. That figure is definitely understated. I point out to the House that many great regional areas in Australia, particularly in the secondary industry and manufacturing areas, are currently experiencing unemployment rates not of 7 per cent or 8 per cent but of 12 per cent and 13 per cent. That is the case in the electorates of Macarthur, Hughes and Cunningham, in the great industrial area around Port Kembla. There is a crisis in the steel industry, a crisis caused by domestic recession, by import penetration, and by backward technology in the steel industry, which is a result of the steel division of the Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd in the boom years of the 1960s and early 1970s taking the money and running instead of reinvesting.

We have a falling consumption pattern. Imports have doubled in the last two years to one million tonnes of raw steel equivalent. In Port Kembla alone 2,000 jobs are already lost. This afternoon I spoke to the BHP steel division in Port Kembla. In the last year 2,000 jobs were lost, 1,425 jobs since June, and the loss of a further 2,000 jobs is expected in the next six or eight months in the steel mills and the ancillary rolling mills and metal shops. That adds up to a direct loss of 4,000 jobs. If we apply a conservative multiplier effect we are looking at another 4,000 jobs. That means that that area alone would lose 8,000 jobs in a little over 18 months to two years, on top of an existing unemployment rate of 12 per cent. When the Government knocked back the industry application to the Temporary Assistance Authority to restrict imports from such countries as Korea to 10 per cent or 15 per cent the responsible Minister said: 'We are looking after these 8,000 people who will lose their jobs through existing manpower programs run by the Commonwealth Employment Service in Wollongong'. He must be joking! I am no simple arch-protectionist, but I understand that in a time of recession and depression we must look after our own and what we have and then try to restructure over the long term. We should not say: 'We have a contracting market in steel and we are going to peg imports at 1981-82 levels, which are historically record levels'. How ridiculous that is.

We need a new approach to the industry and a new approach to steel. The honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume) has not been game to speak out during this debate on steel. He has the hide to go back to the Illawarra region and say : 'Do not worry about it; I will ask the Government for more money for roads'. What we need is Government intervention in the industry. We need a role for the unions, government and steel management together, through a steel industry council. We need an inquiry into steel, a task force inquiry set up on a tripartite level-Government, union and company-to come forward with some long term industry planning policies. Industry assistance will be given in the short term by a Labor government while we restructure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is self-evident that Australia's long term prosperity as a trading nation depends greatly on the size and profitability of our export industries. These industries can be damaged by factors beyond our control, factors such as the present drought and depressed international trading conditions. They can also be damaged by factors which are very much within our control. Of these, the two which are crucial to the prosperity and long term development of our export industries are the effect of industrial action on our capacity to deliver to importers on time and the cost competitiveness of those industries. It is beyond doubt that our world-wide reputation for industrial disruption, especially in the ports and in the major natural resources projects, and the industrial facts of life which have earned us this reputation, have greatly damaged our export industries and have caused our major trading partner, Japan, which accounts for around 27 per cent of our exports, to look elsewhere. This trend, if it continues will put our future prosperity at risk.

SPEECH.PARA: As a nation, we have a duty to the present and to the future to maximise our natural economic advantages. Those advantages are obvious: The wealth of our land, what lies in it, and what we can produce from it. The extent of our dependence on Australia's natural wealth is demonstrated by the fact that around 70 per cent of our export earnings come from agriculture and mining. It is notorious that over the last two decades the major source of growth of exports has been mining. Has that growth come too easily?

With the vast increase in mining developments over the last 20 years, the great interest that overseas investors have shown in those developments, and the high profits made by some in the good years, a kind of cargo-cult mentality has grown up in Australia. A good part of the community seems to hold the view that resource developments are a twentieth century money tree and that all one has to do to get money is shake the tree. Inherent in this mentality is the dangerously erroneous belief, to quote Mr Les Millen of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, that 'resource developments are so profitable that no demand, however extraordinary, need remain unsatisfied if only sufficient industrial muscle were applied'. It is almost an article of faith among many that Australia is so uniquely endowed with natural resources that foreigners, and especially the resource-poor Japanese, will continue to come to us no matter the cost, the inconvenience or the levels of industrial disruption they are forced to endure. Those who believe that resource developments are an endless source of money need look only at the recent catastrophic results of major Australia mining companies .

Those who believe that we are so uniquely wealthy that foreigners will continue to beat a track to our sometimes closed door should look hard at a few facts of our recent industrial history. Firstly, figures produced by the Japanese finance ministry's customs section show that in the six months to the end of June 1982 Australia's share of Japan's coke and coal imports fell to 35.5 per cent compared to 47.7 per cent for the corresponding half year in 1981. In steaming coal, our share of Japan's imports fell from 52.5 per cent for the first half of the calendar year of 1981 to 43.4 per cent for the first half of 1982. In sum, in the first half of 1982 compared to the first half of 1981 we lost 12.2 per cent of Japan's total import market for coal and coke and 9.1 per cent of Japan' s steaming coal market. Those losses were made good by our competitors, who will be determined to retain their increased share in this huge and lucrative market. In iron ore, as reported in the Australian Financial Review on 6 September, the story is the same. Our total share of the Japanese market has declined from a peak of 48.1 per cent in 1976 to 45.2 per cent last year, while our major competitor, Brazil, has increased its share of Japan's market to 23.8 per cent.

The last annual report of the ship owners Mutual Strike Insurance Association shows that insurance claims by ship owners for losses caused by industrial disputes in Australian waters exceeded the combined claims for the rest of the world. The figures for the 12 months to 31 January 1982 show that Australia accounted for an astonishing 51 per cent of all claims. Apart from Canada and the United Kingdom no other country accounted for more than 3 per cent. This was the fourth year in which claims for losses in Australian waters exceeded the combined claims for the rest of the world-testimony of some kind to the national urge to break records. If we keep breaking records in this area we may break the country as well. The direct costs to the Australian economy of this gold medal effort in industrial disruption were estimated by the Association to exceed $ 150m and the indirect costs could exceed $300m. The hidden costs are incalculable.

The gravity of the malaise affecting Australian ports was highlighted by the Minister for Transport and Construction (Mr Hunt) on 18 September 1981. In a statement made that day he pointed out that so far that year there had not been a single day in 1981 which had been completely free of strikes affecting at least some sector of shipping. but our international reputation for industrial instability is not based on port disputes alone. In the period 1975 to 1979, of the 15 countries in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, Australia rated fourth in the incidences of stoppages in all industries and services. The implications of these figures are clear. It is much easier to acquire an international reputation for industrial instability and unreliability in meeting contracts than it is to rid oneself of such a reputation.

Contracts by Japanese companies to acquire what we mine involved the commitment of vast expenditures of money, often over long periods. Because Japan is virtually without any domestic reserves of raw material inputs which its industrial machine needs it is acutely conscious of its vulnerability to shipping delays caused by industrial unrest. There is no reason why the Japanese should have any special solicitude for our industria problems, nor why they should look at the delays that plague our export industries as being anything less than a mark of unreliability and irresponsibility. Given our recent track record it is only logical for Japan to move away from the very heavy reliance it has in the past placed on Australia as its primary source of raw materials for its industries.

Anyone who has visited Japan in the last 12 months and has talked to those involved in the import of those raw materials would have received, if he listened, a very clear message. With some incredulity that Australians could be so short-sighted, that we could wantonly inflict such damage upon ourselves, Japanese industry has made a conscious decision to reduce its dependence on Australia for its raw materials. If this trend persists-and there is no reason why other importers of our raw materials should judge us differently-it must bring several consequences. In the short term, it will bring losses in export earnings. These losses are already reflected in our balance of trade figures which, excluding invisibles, have moved from a surplus which we enjoyed through the 1970s to a deficit of around $3.4 billion in the 1981-82 financial year-a deficit which in turn contributed to a current account deficit of just over $9 billion or around 6 per cent of gross domestic product for that financial year. Of course, in the medium and longer term we face cancelled and deferred developments, a reduced export trade and diminished national prosperity. A drastic reduction in the effect of industrial strife on our export industries is not merely desirable but essential to our survival as a prosperous nation. We are all involved-employers, employees, the Government, the unions and the nation as a whole. We have a great deal to learn, a great distance to travel and little time.

The second of the factors that affect our export industry and one which we can control is cost competitiveness. It is directly and profoundly affected by the levels of wages and salaries. Wage restraint is central not only to our international competitiveness but also more generally to the prosperity and level of employment in our country now and in the future. By international standards and by any sensible reckoning we are living beyond our means. Recent wage settlements in the United States of America and West Germany demonstrate that employees in those countries are coming to realise the truth of the maxim: One man's wage rise is another man's job. In wage negotiations in West Germany this year unions agreed on pay increases which were less than the inflation rate . The same approach to wage increases has been shown by unions in the United States. The motor vehicle industry provides a striking example. Last April workers in the General Motors company voted to ratify a 2 1/2 year agreement under which the United Auto Workers Union agreed to forgo any pay increases during most of the life of the contract and to forgo progress towards a shorter working week. This followed a 'standstill' agreement with the Ford company and a 'give-back' agreement with the Chrysler company.

The need for restraint in wage demands and the acceptance in America of the necessity of increases less than the current rate of inflation were summed up by Mr Art Gundersheim, an official of the 400,000-strong American Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union, as reported in the Bulletin of 20 April this year. He said:

'The worker ultimately feels the availability of a job is more important than his income level. It's a reasonable, rational trade off. In periods of great economic difficulty there have always been concessions. In Chicago in the 60s I can remember workers at one company voting for a 10 per cent wage reduction'.
By contrast to the common sense and restraint summed up by Mr Gundersheim we evince a lemming-like, national determination to use today's pay rises to destroy tomorrow's jobs and opportunities.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics figures for the 1981-82 financial year show that average weekly earnings soared by 17.4 per cent-some 7 per cent above the rate of inflation and in real terms roughly 4 per cent above the increase in gross domestic product for that year. In the same period our rate of inflation was some 4 per cent above the average of our major OECD partners. This means that we are paying ourselves more than we can afford. Given the harsh economic conditions in which we live it is easy to find examples of where this kind of conduct leads. I will give two examples. First, the latest national accounts show that gross operating surpluses of trading enterprises fell by 4 per cent in the December quarter and by 14 per cent in the March quarter. Secondly, a short time ago, and within the space of three days, some 850 jobs were lost in New South Wales following three separate management decisions. The most significant of those decisions was that of Amco Wrangler Ltd to take some of its operations off-shore. This decision is but one example of an ominous trend.

In present economic circumstances no country can afford wage and salary increases that constantly exceed the rate of inflation. Any trading nation that adopts such a course can be perfectly sure of the medium and long term consequences. For Australia those consequences will be: Decreasing international competitiveness which will affect not only our export industries but also our whole manufacturing base as we become more vulnerable to foreign penetration of home markets; the shedding of labour by employers at an increasingly rapid rate; companies and jobs going off-shore, which means a permanent loss of jobs; and insolvencies and company collapses. What can we do? In the Budget the Government offers Australians a clear opportunity and a clear choice-an opportunity for wage and salary restraint in the interests of all, and a choice between community acceptance by Australians of restraint, or a re-run of Whitlam economics, which is what the Australian Labor Party proposes.

The sincerity of the Government is evidenced by its profound commitment to meet the needs of the average and middle wage earner, the family man and those in need. This commitment is demonstrated in this year's Budget by such unarguable benefits which are to become effective on 1 November as: The increase in the tax free zone to $4,595; the reduction in the standard rate of income tax from 32c to 30c in the dollar; the lifting of the threshold from $17,884 to $19,500 at which every extra taxable dollar attracts tax at the rate of 46c; the introduction of a 50 per cent increase in the family allowance for the first and second children; and the allowance of tax rebates at 30c in the dollar on interest payments over 10 per cent on housing loans up to $60,000. Other measures include: Assistance to pensioners and the handicapped; action already taken to counter tax avoidance and proposed action against tax evasion.

These are facts in place-commitments on the record. In return the Government asks, in the national interest, for wage and salary restraint and for no further reduction in hours of work. What is Labor's answer? Three days after the Budget was delivered the Leader of the Labor Party and the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions issued a joint statement. Stripped of its rhetoric the statement has two key elements. The first key element is the adoption, in a centralised system of wage indexation, of full cost of living adjustments, including maintenance in real terms of existing levels of over-award payments, together with a variety of other benefits. Such an approach ignores world economic conditions, ignores Australia's economic condition, ignores the cost to the economy and to Australia's future prosperity and ignores the plight of the many workers who will be thrown out of employment as a direct result of the adoption of this policy. The second key element is the adoption of statutory controls on prices and profits, thinly disguised as a pricing authority with legislative criteria to assess price proposals of corporations within its jurisdiction. Those corporations-the large ones will be the pace setters-will be reassured to know that under Labor they will be allowed to earn reasonable profits-meaning, no doubt, what a Labor government thinks they should get. They would be unwise to hope for generosity, sympathy or even a basic understanding of the economic and financial constraints under which they operate.

Of Labor's proposals it can only be said either that the Labor Party operates in a cocoon of economic ignorance and believes that God made special rules for the Australian economy or that deliberately, and with full knowledge of the economic damage inherent in its proposals, it is willing to put Australians out of work, to destroy future employment prospects and to erode the progress of any future economic recovery-all this in pursuit of putting together a program that it hopes to be electorally palatable. The danger of the mixture of full indexation and other benefits and statutory controls on prices and profits was clearly expressed by Monsieur Jacques Larosier, the Managing Director of the International Monetary Fund, at a management symposium in Davos, Switzerland in March of this year. He said:

There is an urgent need for a more realistic alignment of wage demands with a prospective growth of real output and employment. The restoration of adequate profit margins-to provide the incentive and resources for growth-clearly requires that real wages be held below productivity gains for some time to come. A special problem arises in those countries where wage indexation schemes exist. Schemes of this sort are a many-headed evil.

It is precisely that evil that Labor proposes, and if Monsieur Larosier's criticisms had been specifically directed to Labor they could not have been more apt. The Executive Director of the International Monetary Fund realised the need for restraint. German and American unions accept that in present conditions- conditions not peculiar to Australia but prevalent throughout the world- restraint and acceptance of less than what is needed to keep up with inflation is necessary. Mr Wran, the Premier of New South Wales, to his credit a few weeks ago publicly acknowledged the need for restraint, but not the Federal Labor Party. Labor's answer to our economic problems, and specifically to our need to regain cost competitiveness, amounts to higher wages, increased government expenditure, government job creation-a policy which entirely overlooks the fact that jobs have to be paid for out of taxes or out of profits and that in the long run permanent jobs can be created only out of profits-and control of prices . Controls on prices are the last things we need. They are an active incentive not to invest, not to create jobs and to go off-shore. They stifle initiative, enterprise and profits, and without a profitable employer one cannot have a profitable employee.

The ACTU and the major unions have an historic opportunity to work with the Government and to achieve restraint in regard to salaries, wages and other benefits in the interests of all Australians. To refuse to do so is to consign an increasingly large number of the Australian work force to the bitterness and misery of unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: We are facing an economic disaster. In this Budget the Prime Minister is saying this: 'We, the Liberal Party and the National Country Party, have failed miserably to fulfil any of our promises. Although we failed, it is not our fault ; the fault lies with the world recession'. State governments, trade unions, and even the weather are blamed for Prime Minister Fraser's mistakes. The one thing our beloved Prime Minister is totally consistent about is never accepting responsibility for anything bad that happens in this country. He is responsible only when something good happens. This Budget is an admission of total failure. Having admitted that the Government has failed and that he does not know what to do about the state of the economy, the Prime Minister, in a most incredibly cynical manner, offers a range of goodies to the voters to tempt them to trust him once again. Let me assure the Prime Minister that the old saying-I hate using cliches but one has to be used here-'You can fool some of the people some of the time but you cannot fool all of the people all of the time' was never more appropriate than at this moment.

The Australian voter has a very high threshold of pain when it comes to Australian politicians, particularly conservative politicians, but that threshold was reached just a few months ago. At the last election enough Australian voters still believed that Malcolm Fraser had something up his sleeve besides his arm. They believed him when he said the resources boom which he, the Treasurer (Mr Howard), and the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) trumpeted from one end of the country to another was to eventuate. Enough people were still mesmerised by the pots of gold-the Australian El Dorado; the Liberal Utopia-to give him and his colleagues just one more chance. The Liberals well know that the result of the last election, their 23 seat majority, was very much closer if they look at it in terms of votes and not seats. Nearly all donkey votes in some extremely close results in a number of very marginal seats favoured the Government, but the Government knows as well as we do that a further uniform swing of a little over one per cent would have seen it in opposition. Since then the number of our seats has increased by one and the Government's majority has slipped even further.

The simple fact-I think more and more Government members are reaching this conclusion-is that time has run out. There is a point in the life of every government when the voter no longer believes in anything that it says. No government in Australian history has been given a fairer go than the Fraser Government. Three times the people of Australia have given it a mandate to deliver the promises that the Prime Minister made in 1975. For five years it has had massive majorities in both Houses. For the past two years it has had a comfortable majority in the House of Representatives, whilst in the Senate-I think I am right-only two Bills have been twice rejected. No one in his wildest flights of fantasy could claim that the rejection of either of these Bills has seriously affected the Government's economic policies. Therefore the Government cannot use the excuse that it has not had all the opportunities. It has had solid control of both Houses.

The point has now been reached when people's patience has simply run out. They now know that the Prime Minister has tried everything and blamed everyone but himself for failing to deliver the goods. Whenever the election is held, be it November this year or May or December next year, the people will deliver their verdict clearly and unequivocally. The only question now is the size of the Australian Labor Party's majority. It is well to keep reminding the Government and the people of Australia of the promises which were made by the Prime Minister in his 1975 policy speech. One would not think that it would be exciting to read that document but it is worth while doing so if only for its humour. I will quote some of the statements which were made in the superb document of 1975. It stated:

Let us all as Australians determine to restore prosperity, defeat inflation and provide jobs for all. The Liberal and National Country Parties have prepared a far-reaching programme to restore prosperity and to give effect to our philosophy of freedom, opportunity and concern for the individual.
The document further stated:
What can be done immediately, and must be done, is to establish-for the first time in three years-sound and honest management of Australia's affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —The great economic managers.
—It is hard to believe but it is all on the record, as the honourable member for Cunningham points out. The document also stated:

SPEECH.PARA: We have a comprehensive strategy to restore prosperity.

I am delighted to know that what we have seen in the last seven years has been a strategy. I was concerned that it just happened by accident but it was all planned. The mind boggles at what might have happened if the Government had lacked a strategy, if it had all gone on ad hoc. The document also stated:
The major element in this strategy is to bring about growth in production in the private sector.

In 1975 the Prime Minister said it all and what a dismal, depressing sight this country now is with the mess he has got us into. The situation is grim and it is getting grimmer but all the Prime Minister can do is search around for excuses and people to blame. I would really have some admiration for the Prime Minister if, just once, he would say: 'It is our fault; we take responsibility'. When billions of dollars of projects were being announced he could not get on the air fast enough. He had to push the Treasurer and the Minister for Industry and Commerce out of the way so that he could claim credit for the massive minerals boom that was about to occur in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: — El Dorado.

—That is right, an El Dorado. Now, as projects are being cancelled daily, the Prime Minister is strangely silent on these matters. If there is anyone in Australia who is responsible for workers demanding some share of the cake it must be the Prime Minister because he sold that boom to the people and they, not unnaturally, thought that if it is going to be so good they ought to get their share of it. Most Budgets contain some good things and this one is no exception. There are some things in it that I welcome. The increase in the family allowance is one. That is something that should have been introduced a long time ago by previous governments, both Labor and Liberal. I hope that my party, when we come to government soon, will expand upon that area because I think that that is the area of greatest need in Australia. Many other improvements have been made. SPEECH.PARA: His simplistic Ayn Rand bulldust that he goes on with shows the complete lack of understanding of how the job creation scheme worked. These backwoodsmen come here with simple nostrums and shout and scream at everyone that the only answer to the problem is hard work and productivity.
