SPEECH.SPEAKER: Drummond Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a Budget that the electors of Australia have been waiting for. It is a Budget for families. It leaves more money in the pockets of the taxpayers. For the first time it gives average Australians the incentive to invest in their own and their country's future. I am sure that a lot of people are saying 'It's about time too' on learning of the cuts in income tax. Tax cuts are what the Liberal Party stands for-letting people decide how their earnings should be spent rather than governments grabbing the money and doing it for them. Even critics of the Government have to admit that these cuts are substantial-an extra $7.65 a week for the pay-as-you-earn taxpayer on average earnings of $344 and the raising of the standard rate to $19,500 so that 75 per cent of taxpayers will pay no more than 30c in the dollar.

SPEECH.PARA: It is equally commendable that a special emphasis has been given to assisting those people who have come to feel that they are being left behind-the single income family with a mortgage. The higher spouse rebate, the increased family allowance payments and the extension of interest rate relief to all home buyers will together ease the burden of costs on these families. This does not mean that some of us on the Government back bench will not continue to advocate the splitting of sole breadwinners' incomes for tax assessment as the best long term means of securing tax justice for the single income family, but this Budget is a big step forward.

In the medium term, lower taxation and an increased family allowance give a real incentive for the wage earner and the trade unionist to reject higher wage demands. I appreciate very well that a family struggling with a mortgage and a high personal tax bite will not appreciate the finer points of the need for wage restraint. Now, however, the pressure should be reduced with a tax cut having the same effect as a wage rise. More and more electors are now realising that wages cannot keep rising so far in advance of productivity -least of all when growth is sluggish. High wage demands not only make our industry uncompetitive but also simply price labour out of the market. People become too expensive to employ. Despite the reception given by the Australian Council of Trade Union leadership, which seems more worried about the seizure of the initiative by the Liberal Government than concerned for the long term good of its members, I am hopeful that the rank and file unionists, the very blokes whom this Budget sets out to help, will take a different view. If with their co-operation the so- called trade-off works it will be a very strong blow against inflation.

There are, of course, more long term considerations that are equally important. Within the constraints of economic responsibility every Liberal-National Country Party Government has a duty to work towards the lowering of direct personal tax. We stand committed to maximising incentive and freedom of choice. Shifting some of the tax load to indirect taxation, as this Budget does, gives the taxpayer that extra discretion as to how his dollar will be spent. I have always been wary of sudden lurches into massive indirect taxation of the kind that could disadvantage the low income earner and hamper the small businessman with the weight of administrative bureaucracy. Hence, last year many electors of Forrest were concerned that the projected rise in sales tax was not matched by a reduction in direct taxation. This time, however, there is no denying that the modest rise in sales tax will be more than covered by the cut in income tax and the increases in social security payments.

It does not hurt to point out that Australia in the last available survey of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries ranked low in the scale of the proportion of gross domestic product consumed by indirect taxes-fifteenth on a list of 22, 8 per cent of GDP against a 10 per cent average . Direct taxation, however, accounted for 12 1/2 per cent of GDP. There is in my opinion some room for a gradual shift from direct to indirect taxation provided always that it will not increase the overall tax burden. At this juncture it is appropriate to stress an important advantage of indirect taxation-that it is harder to evade. So often we overlook the fact that the greatest revenue loss comes not through the notorious tax avoidance schemes; it comes through straight concealment of income in small amounts but on a massive scale-the underground economy. On one estimate, this was as much as 10 per cent of gross domestic product. If on both sides of the political divide we are genuinely concerned about tax evasion we cannot afford to condemn the idea of a gradual shift to more indirect taxation. It makes sense to me to curtail the underground economy in this way rather than to pursue thousands of tradesmen and contractors over concealed cash income.

There is a third main source of tax revenue, that is, tax on capital. This Budget is free of that blight, and the people I represent will say 'Amen' to that. As a Liberal I am totally opposed to any seizure by the state of the assets of a citizen and the crippling of his economic liberty that can only erode his freedom. It is one of the great differences that divide liberalism and socialism. I remind the House that it was this Government which in the last Parliament removed the cruellest of all taxes on capital-probate. The inspiration might have come from Queensland, but it was the Fraser Government that abolished it at the national level and thus thwarted the attempt of the Cain Government in Victoria to impose it on the people of Victoria. I will always be proud to have supported a government that has stood up for genuine principles on this matter. It will stand as a blot on the records of previous coalition governments that they tolerated the evil of death duties. People remember well the effect of probate on the farm and the small businessman, the intrusion of the tax gatherer at a time of private grief.

We should remember that when this House removed probate in 1978 the Australian Labor Party was not prepared to vote against such a popular move, yet Opposition speakers made it clear that they held strong commitment to both this and other forms of capital taxation. We heard then and we hear now complaints that Australia is one of the few Western nations without a significant tax on capital . Frankly, this is a fact that makes so many of us proud to be Australians. New Zealand is one of the few countries which are free of poisonous snakes. By the same logic, I suppose, there are people there bemoaning that fact and wanting to import a few.

I wish to make special mention of an important innovation contained in this Budget, that is, the rebate on the first $1,000 of dividend income, which is a saving to the investor of $300 in taxation. The anomaly of taxing company profits twice, first through company tax and then as income in the hands of the shareholder, has been highlighted in the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System and in earlier inquiries. In terms of equity, such double taxation cannot be removed entirely as the practical effect of doing that would leave some fairly affluent people paying no tax at all. The Government, to its great credit, has recognised that the small investor is getting no encouragement to put his savings into Australian enterprises as opposed to real estate. It has for a long time been of concern to me that the average wage earner has thought of the stock market only in terms of speculative capital gain and not as a means of steady income support. There is, of course, a place for some speculation in helping to finance the work of oil and mineral exploration, but for the health of our economy it is essential that more small investors should have a stake in major national enterprises and prosper with them.

Some would say that tax exemption for the first $1,000 of dividend income is not much, but this, nevertheless, ranks as a vital first step. For the first time the small investor has his foot in the door because a Liberal government is acting according to essential Liberal principles. Many of those who will benefit from the rebate are age pensioners. As a society, we must encourage people to provide for their own retirement if we want to avoid a massive burden on taxpayers in years to come. This reform is a part of such a process whereby many people with quite modest incomes might now begin to build up investment portfolios which, by the time of retirement, could return a worthwhile supplement to normal superannuation, thus reducing their need for direct income support through the age pension.

This leads me to the well publicised aspect of the Budget, that is, the assistance it gives to the elderly. Those of us who try to listen carefully to our electors have realised for some time that the concern of many retired people is not so much the level of the pension, now that the Fraser Government's policy of indexation has been operating for some time, but rather the amount of other income they could receive before losing fringe benefits or paying tax. The rise in the other income limit, the raising of the tax threshold, and the pensioner's tax rebate will all help to lessen these anxieties. Of particular concern have been the modest, fixed superannuation payments that could actually disadvantage some age pensioners. The effect of these reforms will be to allow pensioners a total income of some $7,000 before tax is payable, to which we can add a further $1,000 if such income is obtained from dividends. This will enable a pensioner couple to receive $90 per week in other income before losing fringe benefits. In brief, we can applaud the incentive given to elderly people to retain private income.

Of the many changes in the social security policy and payments I would like to single out the new proposal for a family income supplement for the low income family which does not receive social security assistance. I am convinced that such families very often live in rural electorates and that they have found themselves in increasing difficulty in recent years. When this scheme becomes operative next year that extra $10 per dependent child will certainly help these family budgets. Taking a longer view, I consider that we have to get to grips with a fairer division of welfare expenditure. Whilst I am glad that the major spending increases in the social security area are geared towards the family, I cannot rest entirely easily with the fact that the effective increase in total spending for the Department of Social Security has risen some 15.4 per cent to 28.2 per cent of total Budget outlays. On both sides of the House we need to look at ways whereby some proportion of family allowances is directed away from the more affluent to those in need. This is a lot harder than it sounds. For a major saving we would need to place the income test at average weekly earnings which would hardly be a popular measure. Nevertheless, it would seem that some kind of carefully graduated income test must one day be used if we want to assist the low income family without adding to the tax burden and wrecking the economy.

I stand firmly behind the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) in his contention that any attack on poverty must not be made in the universal manner of increasing benefits right across the board, which is the essence of slothful, bureaucratic socialism. In calling for selective welfare to tackle what is being perceived as a growing problem, I do not see why the advocates of such a solution need be confined to the non-Labor side of politics. The honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen) just instanced that type of approach in his speech. Selective welfare should appeal to anyone looking for a fairer means to relieve poverty. In the last few years, reality has dawned on the Liberal Party at the grass roots level that universal welfare can result only in national bankruptcy. Such reality may not, as yet, have caught up with the ALP. Certainly the Family Income Supplement Scheme, whatever its teething problems may be, has the virtue of trying to reach a special area of need on a selective basis.

As the representative of a rural electorate I appreciate the feeling that there is no special good news for the farm sector in this Budget other than the wiping off of the beef producers' debt for the brucellosis eradication campaign. Nonetheless, farmers are also taxpayers, family people and investors and their position can hardly be viewed in isolation. Total Budget outlays in the agricultural sector of $310m show an increase of some 40 per cent on the last financial year. I am also very confident that should the drought worsen on a national basis, as it is in the process of doing, unfortunately, the Federal Government has demonstrated that it stands ready to respond. The response it has given is very humane and justified. Furthermore, the farm sector remains hopeful that the Government will resist added protection demands which weaken our competitive position on overseas markets. I have some reservations as to the operation of the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme on the grounds that it may involve cumbersome paper work without any great saving to the taxpayer. I also note comments by the fishing industry that such large users of diesel fuel would be carrying a major additional cost while awaiting the rebate. If indeed the new scheme proves unsatisfactory I would hope that speedy alterations might be made.

The increase in the retention allowance for private companies from 70 per cent to 80 per cent is welcome news for the small business sector and continues the process begun by this Government three years ago when the allowance was raised from 50 per cent. I am hopeful that small business will benefit from increased consumer spending that will more than offset the rise in sales tax and excise. One group of small businessmen in my electorate of Forrest who perhaps have cause to be satisfied with this Budget are the wine growers who have avoided the introduction of a wine excise. I am delighted that the Fraser Government has again shown the foresight to avoid such an imposition on an industry that is largely still establishing itself-that is, within the electorate of Forrest. It has been demonstrated in the south west of Western Australia that we can grow wines equal to those produced in any part of Australia, indeed the world. But it is still a fledgling industry in my electorate.

Finally, both as the member for an electorate where tourism is a major industry and as Chairman of the Government Members' Committee on Tourism I welcome the continuing support for the tourist industry by this Government. Not only has a record $9.7m been allocated for overseas promotion by the Australian Tourist Commission but the industry incentive package of last month extended a depreciation allowance of 2 1/2 per cent to all buildings in the tourist industry. This continues the initial advance made three years ago when the allowance was granted for accommodation buildings. In the same package the Export Market Development Grants Scheme was amended to raise the maximum grant to tourist operators to $200,000, to waive the minimum spending requirements of $5,000 and to extend eligibility. The fact that tourism is no longer the poor relation of more favoured industries is a sign that in this field, as in many others, the Fraser Government is keeping well up front with reality.

The Government has set the scene. The Government continues to give this country sound, honest management. Basically the future is in our own hands. It it up to us, every member of society, as to how much he or she is prepared to contribute as against how much he or she wishes to take out. I believe it would require very little effort on everyone's behalf to turn our economy into a vibrant, healthy, fully employed economy with a secure future for all of us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mountford Mr J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to join the debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) which forms the major thrust of the Government's Budget presented to the Parliament three weeks ago. The 1982 Budget is a reversal of recent previous Budgets in that it proposes to loosen the tight monetary rein for politically expedient reasons in an attempt to give the Government the advantage in the forthcoming election. But the Australian people have been down this road before. They have experienced similar deceptions in the 1977 Budget which was brought down only months before an election was called. The Government offered tax cuts, it maintained tax indexation and offered a range of goodies. These supposedly responsible economic managers estimated that the cost of all those Budget measures would lead to a Budget deficit of only $1.4 billion. Three months later the Government went to the polls and won. Almost immediately after it became apparent that the Budget had blown out. The deficit was heading towards $2.5 billion. The Government had given the electorate the goods before the election but had wrongly calculated the costs.

SPEECH.PARA: In the 1978 Budget the Government took back its tax concessions, it backed down on its promised full tax indexation and it introduced the oil levy so that in one year the Government's revenue from oil and liquefied petroleum gas jumped from $800m to $1.3 billion. Medibank was dismantled and health insurance became more expensive, excise taxes were increased and there were further increases in sales tax and other indirect taxes. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) estimated that these measures put an extra 2 per cent on our inflation figure each year. People were told to tighten their belts, that life was not going to be easy. They experienced further deception in 1980 when the Government fabricated the resources boom. Suddenly they were told that Australia was once again the lucky country and that all Australians could expect to share the benefits of exceptional growth and national development. But the resources boom collapsed soon after the 1980 elections. Many big projects were either shelved or cancelled, for example, the Rundle shale oil project, the Alcan, Lochinvar and Portland aluminium smelters and the now ironic proposal to expand the Newcastle steel works.

The Australian people are awake to the Fraser Government's not having a sound economic framework as the basis for its policy decisions. They are awake to the reality of the Government's lurching from one election to the next, trying to bring down the policies which may get it re-elected but which will not get Australia out of its chronic economic malaise. I think the Australian people are awake to the fact that the Budget now before Parliament is another cynical exercise in political expediency.

The scenario for this situation was devised some months ago. First, we saw the Government introduce some incentives for the business community by way of increased depreciation allowances and plant investment allowances, et cetera, prior to the Budget so that maximum publicity could be obtained for those measures. I shall deal with these measures a little later. Secondly, we have the present Budget which provides, on the face of it, a basketful of goodies for the middle income earner, the swinging voter and some relief for our pensioner population. It is a Budget designed for an early election because of the hand- outs it proposes and because it lacks any provision for a reversal of the present poor economic condition of our country. It is a Budget which will do nothing to get the economy moving again. By the admission of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) we will have virtually no real growth and increased unemployment. It is a hotch-potch recipe for economic disaster for Australia in the long term.

As the Leader of the Opposition has stated, in this Budget the Government has again used rubbery and downright deceptive figures. By understating expenditure and overstating income the Government is attempting to show that the deficit will be only $1,674m. This is an act of downright deception which will be seen by the community in its true light at the end of this financial year. That is another reason why the Government is so eager to have an election. It could then do what it did in 1978 after the election in 1977-take back the tax cuts six months after they were given. Even the so-called basket of goodies is deceptive. Three major problems facing my constituents in the electorate of Banks-and I am sure facing most Australians-have, according to the Treasurer, been addressed in this Budget. They are taxation, housing and unemployment. A closer look at the Government's Budget measures shows that the basket of goodies has a false bottom or does not address the real problem.

First, I will deal with the tax measures. What are these tax measures? The Government has said that from November 1982 it will increase the tax threshold from $4,195 to $4,595 and the 46c tax threshold from $17,894 to $19,500. As well , the 32c in the dollar tax scale will be reduced to 30c. Accompanying these changes indirect taxes will be increased. On the face of it the measures, excluding the indirect tax increases, seem favourable. For a long time the Australian Labor Party has been urging the Government to grant some compensation . In context, however, the Government offers very little to most Australians. I have two major areas of complaint. First, the measures offer only little more than what full indexation would have given them. Secondly, it offers only a small reversal of the seven years of a regressive tax system.

On the first point, the tax concessions announced with such grandiosity in reality amount to only a little over what the taxpayer would have been entitled to under promised automatic tax indexation. The cost of the concessions in 1982- 83 is estimated to be $1.6 billion, whereas the cost of full indexation is $1.5 billion. The Liberal Party praised the merits of tax indexation in 1975 when it promised to reform the tax system. Tax indexation it said would make government more honest with taxpayers' money because government would no longer be able to rely on the secret tax increase of inflation. These words were spoken by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in 1975. Yet over the proceeding years that commitment was rarely met. For the six financial years from 1976-77 to 1981-82 inclusive full tax indexation was applied only twice. In three of the remaining years half tax indexation was applied and in 1979-80 there was no tax indexation at all. Seen in this context, this Budget's tax concessions do not give much to the taxpayer; they simply stop the practice of automatically taking the hidden tax increases that inflation permits. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. Over the past seven years the lower the income of a taxpayer with a dependent spouse and two children, as shown in the table, the greater proportion of his income he has had to pay in tax. For example, a person who now earns $12,062 pays 6.4 per cent of his income in tax. In 1975-76 he paid 1.6 per cent. The proportion has increased in this period by 300 per cent. I compare this with a person earning $36,187. He now pays 30 per cent of his income in tax. In 1975-76 he paid 29.3 per cent. The increase is only 2.3 per cent. It is only when we get into even higher income groups that that percentage has decreased. We now see that when the Prime Minister said in the 1975 election campaign that his Government would reduce the tax burden he must have meant that the burden would be reduced for only a very select group of taxpayers, that is, the richer ones.

SPEECH.PARA: So much for the Budget's tax cuts. What about the housing measures? The Government has said that this Budget addresses the housing problem. I dispute this claim for several reasons. First, what is the housing problem? There are three main groups in our community who are experiencing a housing problem. Firstly, there are those people who are in the private rental market and are unlikely ever to be in a position of purchasing their own homes. This is the long term housing problem which faces the lower income groups in society. Secondly, there are those people who are in the private rental market and who are likely to be able to afford their own homes. These are the people currently faced with the deposit gap. Thirdly, there are those people who have already committed themselves to the purchase of houses but who are currently experiencing cash flow problems as a result of rising interest rates. This group , comprising primarily middle income earners, is in need of short term assistance.

What has the Government done for the first group? All the Budget does for this group, which makes up 25 per cent of the population, is to allocate $10m in rent relief assistance. This compares with the $562m package to home purchasers who represent approximately 25 per cent of the Australian population. The Government has also increased supplemenatary assistance to pensioners in rented accommodation but by a mere $2 a week. Rentals are rising at an annual rate of more than $10 a week. If the Government were serious in alleviating the housing problem for this group it would extend considerably the access to public rental housing. The Government-I give it credit for this-has increased the welfare housing share in this Budget but over the past eight years in real terms the money it has spent on welfare housing has declined, in 1982-83 prices, from $ 975m in 1974-75 to $290m in 1982-83. The cumulative real reduction in public housing funding over that period is a staggering $3,740m.

The second group comprises those people who are unable to bridge the deposit gap, that is, the people who are eligible for the maximum home loan which is far exceeded by the cost of a home. Only two courses of action are open to a person in this position. Either he rents accommodation until he can save the deposit or he obtains a second mortgage. For the person who takes the first option this Budget offers little to no help. He will still be paying $90 to $100 a week in rent and if he has enough money to save he will pay tax on the interest his savings earn. The person who takes the second option will receive some assistance through the interest rebate, which I will deal with later. But his more basic problem, that of having to obtain a second mortgage, is not recognised at all. By tightening the money supply the Government is, in fact, making it harder for him to get finance.

The third group comprises the people who purchased houses recently and are now finding it difficult to cope with interest rate rises. Many people within my electorate are experiencing such a problem. In recent years several new subdivisions have been opened up to home buyers in the Milperra, Padstow Heights and Lugarno areas. Those who thought they could afford to buy homes in early 1980 have had to evaluate their positions. Since then savings banks' interest rates have risen from 9.5 per cent to 13.5 per cent. This 4 per cent increase has meant that repayments on a $30,000 loan have risen from $262 a month to $350 a month-an annual increase of $1,056. Many home owners are struggling to maintain their mortgages. Statistics on mortgage defaults from the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation show that between 1970-71 and 1979-80 mortgage defaults have increased from 4 per cent of total premiums to 35 per cent. Under the March scheme the maximum rebate he could anticipate was $300 this year. Under the Budget rebate scheme this amount will be $377.50. TALK.START.PARA: —Secondly, the Government delivers a Budget which has a no-growth strategy as its basis. By budgeting for a $240m domestic surplus the Government is taking money out of the pockets of wage and salary earners and out of the profits of firms facing severe liquidity and investment problems. The foreign deficit does nothing to generate jobs in Australia. By restricting the growth in the money supply to 9 per cent to 11 per cent, just enough to accommodate the expected inflation rate of 10.75 per cent, it provides no capacity for growth. To hold unemployment at its present level we must achieve an annual growth of at least 3 per cent. This means aiming at a domestic deficit and an increase in the money supply-the reverse of the Fraser Government's policies.

INTERJECT.PARA: Thirdly, the Government says that it is increasing its manpower training programs by 21 per cent for 1982-83. On the face of it, it is a welcome increase but when seen in the context of the overall Budget, which forecasts no employment growth in 1982-83, it is ludicrous. The Government can talk all it likes about grandiose schemes to retrain the unemployed, but the reality is that the jobs are not there even when they gain the skills. Fourthly, and it is hardly worth mentioning, the Government has increased the unemployment benefits in the Budget. The increase of $4 a week in benefits for the under-18-year-olds represents an 11 per cent increase in seven years. For those unemployed who are over 18 years their benefit of $64.40 is still $26.70 below the poverty line. These measures are a total insult to those unemployed because of the Government' s own economic policies.

In conclusion, let me say that I am disappointed with the Government's strategies in managing the Australian economy. Where we should have seen increasing productivity and employment, we have instead seen low growth and increasing unemployment. The Government has blindly followed the United States of America and the United Kingdom down the Friedman economic path of recession and depresson. The world is now on the brink of economic depression because the major countries of the West have pursued wrong policies-policies that were based on political expediency. In Australia we need a government of vision, a government that has faith in the future, a government that is willing to forgo short term, stop-go policies of expediency in favour of long term economic stability which will improve our people's standard of living. We need a leader who will unite our people in a true nationalistic spirit.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw to the attention of the House a Press statement issued by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) on 27 August 1982 in which he indicated the Government's support for the proposition of greater uniformity in liability in repatriation legislation. He indicated that it was the Government's intention that repatriation legislation be amended to provide greater uniformity in Commonwealth liability to provide benefits to veterans and their dependants. He specifically indicated that the proposed amendment was designed to remove existing anomalies within the legislation which deprived veterans, particularly those who had taken part in the Vietnam war, of entitlements equivalent to those for those veterans who had fought in earlier conflicts on behalf of this nation. Of course, that was basically an endorsement of the policies and of the views which had been argued for and on behalf of the Opposition in this House in April of this year. Not being one who would ever want to look a gift horse in the mouth and not wanting to be churlish about this matter, I would have been perfectly happy to compliment the Minister and the Government on this much needed amendment had it not been for what seemed to me to be an exercise in politicking by the Minister at the end of his Press statement. I rather suspect that he said what he did at the end of the statement out of a feeling of guilt. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has needed no prodding on this issue and it is significant that the legislation changes it proposes are broader than those proposed by other parties.

To say that the Government needed no prodding on this issue is, I suggest, an indication of the guilty mind of the Minister. In March of this year there was before this House a Repatriation Amendment Bill. An amendment was moved on that occasion by my colleague the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) which was seconded by me. That amendment contemplated the very amendment which is now contemplated by the Minister. On that occasion the Minister handling the Bill on behalf of the Government in this House indicated that the Government could not accept that amendment. A division was called and every honourable member on the Government side of the House followed the view expressed by the Government and cast his or her vote against any changes in the legislation. I indicated that I thought this was the kind of amendment which should have attracted support from both sides of the House and I urged the Government to examine what seemed to me to be the justice of that claim while the legislation passed between this place and the Senate.

The Bill was debated in the Senate in April 1982 and the very same amendment was moved in the Senate. On that occasion Government supporters again used their numbers to reject any such proposal. Some four months later the Government has suddenly changed its mind on the very issue which its members were not prepared to consider appropriate or just in March or April of this year. Yet the Minister says: 'We did not need any prodding'. What caused this change was the decision of the Vietnam Veterans Association to campaign in marginal seats for what was plain justice. I commend it for its actions and decision. I salute the result it has already achieved for its members from its action. I can only hope that the Minister, having conceded the justice of this occasion, will now consider the claim for further justice and grant these people the judicial inquiry they have sought for so long.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 March 1964 a British court in Aylesbury, Buckinghamshire, convicted 10 men for their involvement in the #2.5m 1963 British mail train robbery. They were sentenced by Mr Justice Edmund Davies on 16 April of that year to prison terms ranging up to 30 years. Explaining the severity of the sentences Davies said to those he was sentencing:

SPEECH.PARA: Potential criminals . . . dazzled by the size . . . of the prize must be taught that punishment will be proportionately greater; let us clear any romantic notions . . . it is . . . a sordid crime of violence inspired by vast greed . . . it would be an affront if you were at liberty in the near future to enjoy these ill-gotten gains.

Those convicted included Ronald Arthur Biggs, then 34 years, a carpenter. Biggs, a member of the gang that executed that robbery, escaped from Wandsworth prison in London on 8 July 1966 with three other prisoners. Of course, we know the record of his activities in Australia where he lived for some time under an alias. We know that the police suspect Biggs of having been involved in robberies in Australia. We know that he fled Australia leaving his wife and family to fend for themselves. We know of his history in the West Indies and in South America. We know that he fathered a child to a Brazilian woman so that he could remain in Brazil and we know that the many attempts that were made by the British authorities to have him extradited to Great Britain have failed.

In recent days we have seen in newspapers in Australia the same Ronald Arthur Biggs advertising a particular brand of coffee. The Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations refused to accept the commercials that featured Ronald Biggs selling that coffee, but unfortunately full page advertisements have been run in some newspapers suggesting that people buy the brand of coffee Cafe de Rio. I just hope that when people take notice of that advertisement and think that it is very clever-obviously it was a good idea on the part of the advertising agency-they will remember that the guard on that train lost his life to make Biggs notorious to an extent that he could be hired by an Australian advertising agency, no doubt at very great cost, to make this commercial.

We know that Ronald Biggs has featured in Press advertisements and television advertisements which were never shown. The latest estimate that I can gain on what he may have been paid to undertake this promotion was in excess of $A35,000 . I believe that the advertising agency should be condemned and that the manufacturers of that brand of coffee should also be condemned for even considering having this man involved in the promotion of their product. I make a plea to the people of Australia: The next time they are in a supermarket and see the coffee brand Cafe de Rio, avoid it like the plague.

TALK.START.PARA: —Five weeks ago my wife and I spent a few days in Kakadu National Park.
—How did it go?

—It was very interesting, as the honourable member will hear in a moment. We were interested to look at several of the issues involved there: Firstly, the situation of the Aboriginal people; secondly, the effect of uranium mining on the area; and thirdly, what was actually happening to the park. There is a conflict of interests in that area. From my observations and from discussions I had with, for example, the rangers in the park, Aboriginal people, and the people involved in uranium mining I believe that this conflict will become more accentuated in the future. There seem to be so many different concepts of the future of that area and what will happen to it. I wish to deal firstly with the proposed uranium mines at Jabiluka and Koongarra, which are massive projects. One of those projects has been approved by the Northern Territory Government. That approval was obtained after supposed extensive discussions with the Aboriginal people in the area. In my discussions with them I found that tactics of intimidation and attempted bribery had been used over those people to attempt to force them into a position where they finally gave way to the demands from the companies involved in uranium mining at Jabiluka.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to contrast that situation with the situation in an area further south but still in the park-the Koongarra mine. The Aboriginal people there, organised by the Gagudju Association, have rejected the proposals for uranium mining in the area and in rejecting those proposals they have created a crisis for the Northern Territory Government. To this stage the Northern Territory Government has been able to use one technique or another to force the Aboriginal people to accept these kinds of mining leases. Some of the reasons why the Aboriginal people rejected the Koongarra mine apply to all of the mines in that area. In fact, some of those reasons apply to the problems faced in the whole park area. The first and major reason is that the Koongarra mine is close to a major sacred site, the home of the lightning god of the Aboriginal people in the area. Given that situation, they are understandably very reluctant to allow mining in that place. If one visits that area one finds that is an absolutely beautiful part of Australia that would be totally ruined by a uranium mine, especially when one takes into account the weather conditions that exist and the roads and other works that would have to be built.

Already in the middle of the Kakadu Park is a town called Jabiru and it is anticipated that in the next six months to 12 months Jabiru will have a population of 1000. It is a quite extraordinary contradiction to drive through a park which has Aboriginal settlements and so forth and suddenly to come upon this town, which is like a suburban shopping centre in the middle of a city such as Sydney or Melbourne. It is such a total contradiction and it is so out of place in that area. If the uranium mines go ahead, it is intended that the town will have-these are not my words but the words of the people at the Ranger mine- a population of 10,000 people; that is to say, more than 10 times the total Aboriginal population of the area.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning I questioned the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) on a matter of great concern to me and to the people of my electorate. I refer to our tariff laws and a situation of a tariff in reverse. The Phillips tractor company of Merredin is situated in a town approximately half way between Perth and Kalgoorlie, 260 kilometres from Perth. It is central to the eastern wheat belt of Western Australia and has a population of approximately 4,000 people. It is a relatively large town in Western Australian terms. Laurie Phillips, who has been a resident there for many years, commenced manufacturing four wheel drive agricultural tractors in 1975. His decision to choose the town of Merredin could be justified only by its proximity to the customers. As a present day employer of 50 people, Mr Phillips stands as my ideal of an operater of a successful and decentralised business. He is taking advantage of the position but, more importantly, he is creating work for people who choose not to work in city areas but wish to gain some of the benefits provided by country living. His production over the first five years averaged 13 tractors a year. This was caused more by his lack of working capital than by a lack of orders. He just manufactured to order, factory direct, as he could neither afford stock on hand nor agent's commission.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1980 Mr Phillips took a partner and appointed agents both in Western Australia and interstate. These moves saw sales rise to 47 tractors in 1981 and to a predicted 70 tractors in 1982. His range of tractors has also increased and now varies from a 249 horsepower, four wheel drive, manual drive machine at a price of about $70,000 to a 515 horsepower, power shift model at $251,000. Laurie has tended to keep ahead of imported tractors both in horsepower and in equipment such as power shift. I can tell honourable members that, from observing his tractors myself, they are advanced models which are attractive to the farming community in this day and age of big equipment. Nevertheless, it is natural with such a small volume producer that Phillips utilise imported mechanical components such as Mercedes engines and Japanese transmissions and axles. The success of his combination is evident from the fact that the first machine sold is still in active service although the purchaser now owns a second machine. That gentleman has resisted all overtures to sell the original machine back to the Phillips company.

There is a problem. The Federal revenue duty of 2 per cent is applicable to all his imported components. This represents a cost of $600 to $900 a tractor and, in terms of the Phillips production level, about $1,000 a week. Unfortunately for this small and viable four wheel drive tractor manufacturer his competitors, who are importing fully built up four wheel drive tractors from the United States of America in particular, do not pay this duty. In fact they pay no import duties at all. A General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade conference of the past, no doubt recognising that Australia had no manufacturers in this area, saw a duty-free deal in fully built up, four wheel drive tractors as a logical trade -off for concessions overseas in other trade areas. Mr Phillips is quite happy to meet head on and on equal terms the competition from the big time overseas competitors. However, because of this GATT agreement his competitors escape the 2 per cent revenue duty. In addition, the percentage of imported components denies him access to the tractor bounty.

Only recently the Government announced that it would dispose of the 2 per cent revenue duty for ships manufactured overseas and imported into this country. I am therefore at a loss to know why for 18 months the Government has constantly advised me that there is no way in which a similar arrangement can be made for people in this manufacturing area. It is unbelievable that such a simple solution cannot be provided. In a highly protected nation such as ours we have a situation where some local manufactures are actually being hit by duty which is not applicable to imported components.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In respect of the Minister's Department and statutory authorities within his jurisdiction, has there been (a) medical examinations of all workers and (b) an ergonomic assessment of the work process, tasks and work environment made by an ergonomist in all areas where repetitious injuries, for example, tenosynovitis and carpal tunnel syndrome, have been reported; if not, why not.
(2) If so, (a) when were assessments made and (b) what recommendations were made.
(3) Have any recommendations been carried out; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) and (3). No comprehensive medical examinations beyond those included in the appointment process are conducted routinely. Medical examinations are, however, arranged when officers or employees report symptoms of apparently job related illnesses.

The significance of repetition strain injury as an occupational health problem has only recently been recognised. My Department has reacted promptly in researching the problem and it is expected that a National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) Occupational Health Guide will be issued in the near future. My Department and statutory authorities within my portfolio will make every effort, subject to the availability of resources, to comply with NHMRC recommendations.

My Department is continuing to consider this problem and to seek advice from relevant authorities on suitable working environments for operators where the possible existence of health hazards is suspected. Existing work places have, of course, been designed, fitted out and equipped having regard to recent Government and State safety regulations and relevant standards and guidelines issued by such bodies as the Standards Association of Australia, the NHMRC and the Department of Science and Technology.

In accordance with the Guidelines on Technological Change issued by the Public Service Board, my Department is consulting with staff associations regarding re- equipment programs in some of its major processing areas. The ergonomic aspects of equipment and work processes in the areas concerned are covered in those consultations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McMahon Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 21 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: In respect of the Minister's Department and statutory authorities within his jurisdiction,

(a) what steps have been taken to make operators of visual display units and screen based equipment aware of the need for a sufficient break from operating this equipment, having regard to the nature of the task and the need for involvement in substantially different activities during the break, as per Public Service Board memorandum 81/418 entitled 'Operation of Visual Display Units and other Screen Based Equipment'.
(b) what percentage of their working day (i) are operators expected to spend on operating duties and (ii) do operators spend on other duties and
(c) how many keystrokes per 7 hour 21 minute day (i) are operators expected to complete and (ii) do operators actually complete.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Public Service Board memorandum 81/418 has been brought to the attention of all supervisors and operators in the Department. Copies of the memorandum have also been provided to the statutory authorities for which the Attorney-General has responsibility; although it should be noted that some of those authorities have autonomous powers in relation to the matters in question. Operators in the Department, in consultation with supervisors, take regular breaks from operating this equipment to perform other tasks or to take basic rest periods.

(b) The percentage of the working day spent on operating duties depends on the nature of the task being performed and it is therefore difficult to give a precise answer. However, experience in the Department indicates that no operators spend more than 75% of their day on operating duties.

(c) (i) The general practice in the Department is for the output required of an operator to be determined by the nature and complexity of the task being performed and there is no requirement to complete a number of keystrokes within any specific time frame. Operators are expected to complete a reasonable number of keystrokes according to the task being undertaken. (ii) No statistics are maintained by the Department on keystrokes completed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McMahon Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 21 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: In respect of the Minister's Department and statutory authorities within his jurisdiction, (a) what steps have been taken to make operators of visual display units and screen based equipment aware of the need for a sufficient break from operating this equipment, having regard to the nature of the task and the need for involvement in substantially different activities during the break, as per Public Service Board memorandum 81/418 entitled 'Operation of Visual Display Units and other Screen Based Equipment', (b) what percentage of their working day (i) are operators expected to spend on operating duties and (ii) do operators spend on other duties and (c) how many keystrokes per 7 hours 21 minute day (i) are operators expected to complete and (ii) do operators actually complete.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) operators have been made aware of the need for breaks by supervisors and/or by circulars and are permitted regular breaks from operating their equipment.

(b) The percentage of the working day occupied on operating duties varies considerably depending on the system utilised and work organisation. Where operators spend 100 per cent of their working time on operating duties they are allowed regular breaks additional to lunch and morning and afternoon tea. In systems where operators spend a substantial proportion of their time on other duties the work arrangements themselves provide time away from equipment operating duties.

(c) The type of equipment and the processing system used influence the rates of output expected from operators. Operators who use screen based equipment for processing medical benefits and similar claims are expected to complete, on average, 48,750 keystrokes per 6 1/2 hour day (7,500 per hour). The 6 1/2 hour day is based on a 7 hour 21 minute day less morning and afternoon tea breaks and rest breaks. Actual keystrokes rates vary between approximately 7,500 per hour and 12,000 per hour. In a number of operational systems there is no requirement to complete a set number of keystrokes per day because of the nature of the work involved, for example, checking the information shown on a visual display unit.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 19 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the cost estimates used for planning and funding purposes by the Tertiary Education Commission required for each equivalent full-time student ( EFTS) in colleges of advanced education in Australia in (a) teacher education, ( b) science based courses and (c) commerce/social science/humanities based courses in each State and Territory in 1982, 1983 and 1984.

(2) What are the average funded costs for each EFTS in the colleges of advanced education in (a) teacher education, (b) science based courses and (c) commerce/ social science/humanities based courses for (i) Australia, (ii) each State and Territory and (iii) each individual college of advanced education for 1982, 1983 and 1984.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The factors which were taken into account by the ad- vanced education Council in preparing its Advice to the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission (CTEC) in respect of recommendations for funding in the 1982-84 triennium are set out at paragraph 8.27 et seq of Volume 1, Part 3 of the Commission's 'Report for 1982-84 Triennium'. The average cost estimate used by the Advanced Education Council was approximately $4,000 per equivalent full-time student (EFTS), which represented a 5.5 per cent increase on the existing level of support. The figure is expressed in estimated December 1980 costs levels. The CTEC did not support in full the Advanced Education Council's funding proposals (see paragraph 8.52 to 8.57 of Volume 1 Part 1 of the Commission's Report). It recommended a level of general recurrent funding some 5 per cent below that sought by the Council.

(2) In accordance with long standing arrangements, recurrent grants to higher education institutions are allocated by the Commonwealth on the basis of a block grant. The expenditure of that grant, including the allocation of funds to particular disciplines or areas of teaching, is a matter for the institution to determine. Consistent with this policy, the CTEC does not publish cost parameters used in developing its recurrent grant recommendations.

In the case of colleges of advanced education, these recommendations are based on advice from State authorities, in accordance with an agreement between the Commonwealth and State Ministers for Education made in June 1979. Under this arrangement, the allocation of funds for recurrent purposes in the advanced education sector by the CTEC is based on the folowing procedures:

(a) The total number of advanced education students and their mix in terms of individual institutions and fields and levels of study in a given State will be determined by the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission on the advice of the Advanced Education Council after consultation with State authorities.

(b) The Commission, on the advice of the Advanced Education Council, will allocate the available funds to individual colleges after advice to the Council from the appropriate State authorities. As the development of individual colleges is largely a matter for the States in the light of co-ordinated State plans for advanced education, the Council will generally follow the recommendations made by the State authorities.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 6 May 1982:

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

(2) Implementation is on-going. The Government has taken various initiatives to enhance the status, and increase awareness, of Australian citizenship. These initiatives include amendment of the Commonwealth Electoral Act to make Australian citizenship the basis for the franchise and for nomination for Parliament; a Task Force of the Australian Council on Population and Ethnic Affairs has examined citizenship enhancement strategies; a study of the factors which lead people to take out citizenship has been commissioned and is now completed; a review of the initiatives and measures in other countries, especially the ways and means of greater involvement of the community in the acquisition of citizenship, is underway. The national registration body will have responsibility for the maintenance of standards-corresponding with the five levels of accreditation established by NAATI-for testing and other forms of assessment, for accreditation and for registration. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 6 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to Labour Forces Survey Data in January 1982 which shows that unemployed workers in the 60-64 year age bracket are expected to remain unemployed for an average of 2 years.
(2) Would those same people, in January 1981, only have remained unemployed for an average of 43 weeks.
(3) Do many older unemployed workers drop out of the job market when they discover the limited job opportunities available and the age discrimination by employers.

(4) What steps has his Department taken or will be taking to tackle the problems of age discrimination by employers and the psychological trauma suffered by older workers who are forced out of the work force and must remain unemployed for longer periods of time.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) I am informed by the Australian Statistician that there are no official statistics which show that in January 1982 unemployed workers in the 60 -64 year age bracket were expected to remain unemployed for an average of two years.

The monthly labour force survey conducted by the Australian Bureau of Statistics produces estimates of the actual duration of unemployment up to the time of the survey-not the expected duration-for the following four age groups: 15-19; 20-24; 25-34; 35-54.

Information is compiled by the ABS for certain other age groups but, because the number of people in these categories who are selected in the sample is very small, the figures are not reliable because of the associated large sampling errors.

(3) The most recent statistics available on persons, classified by the ABS as ' discouraged job seekers' (that is, persons who wanted a job but were not actively looking for work because, for a variety of reasons, they believed they would not be able to find a job) were collected in September 1981. It is estimated that in September 1981 there were about 9,100 discouraged job seekers 55 to 64 years of age who thought they would be considered by prospective employers to be too old to work. Source: ABS Supplementary Labour Force Survey, September 1981 (unpublished data).

(4) My Department is currently undertaking an examination of the position of older unemployed job seekers registered with the Commonwealth Employment Service so that appropriate assistance can be given. In addition, my Department's Bureau of Labour Market Research is planning a major study of unemployment among older workers which is due to be completed by June next year. This information will further increase my Department's capacity to develop soundly-based measures of assistance to counter employment disadvantages suffered by older workers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Young Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 6 May 1982:

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The numbers of applications for citizenship have been increasing for some time and are currently 38 per cent above application levels last year. This higher application rate has resulted in the delays experienced in the processing of applications for citizenship.

The current average national processing time between date of receipt of an application for Australian citizenship until date of decision (approval or refusal) is 22 weeks. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Johnson The Hon L.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has he received a submission from the National Secretariat of the Australian Electric Vehicle Association seeking exemption from sales tax for components used in the after market conversion of motor vehicles to electric drive; if so, has the Government given consideration to the possible saving on fuel bills to this country by the introduction of more electric vehicles.
(2) Will the Government, in the interests of the future conservation of power resources in Australia, give aid to this industry to provide a viable alternative to the petrol driven vehicle.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The submission referred to has been received by the Treasurer and has been considered.

(2) It is appreciated that electric-powered motor vehicles can have a number of advantages over petrol-powered alternatives. Most of these advantages would, however, benefit directly the purchaser of the vehicle who can be expected to weigh such benefits against the relative purchase prices of the two types of vehicle. It is relevant here that the Government's policy of import parity pricing of crude oil is itself broad encouragement to shift from petrol-powered vehicles to those using alternative sources of energy. In the circumstances, there appears to be no need for additional incentives to encourage the use of electric power in the transport area.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Independent Audit of Funds Granted to Non-government Organisations

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: What independent audit is required by the Minister's Department to ensure the proper expenditure of funds granted to non-government organisations by the Minister or the Minister's Department.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The requirements of my Department are prescribed in Finance Directions Section 13/13 issued by the Secretary, Department of Finance, pursuant to Finance Regulation 127A. Essentially the Department requires organisations to vouch the proper expenditure of funds provided either in their normal audited financial statements in the case of general assistance grants or, in the case of specific purpose grants, by providing separate statements prepared by a qualified public accountant who is not a member of the organisation.

In the case of grants made under the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Act 1976, technical and cost investigation staff of the Board established under that Act perform technical and financial audits in relation to funds provided and the purposes for which they were provided.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 May 1982 (Hansard, page 2334) Mr Hayden asked me a question without notice concerning two reports by a person who was formerly an Army Investigator. He asked whether I was aware of the existence of a second report which, he indicated, dealt with illegal activities by Nugan Hand, their associates and other persons who are prominent in public life.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
I advised on 6 May that I was aware of the existence of one report and undertook to check further to see whether there was a second report.

A copy of the second report has since been located. It is dated 17 February 1971 and was a follow-up report to the first report dated 19 January 1971. The first report had dealt primarily with some Army personnel involvement with black marketing; the second report had dealt with civilian personnel that came to notice during the black marketing investigation.

I am advised that careful examination of the report has failed to reveal any such mention or evidence of any connections with Nugan Hand, their associates or other persons prominent in public life. This view has been reached after enquiry into the appropriate Department of Defence records and enquiries to the Commonwealth/New South Wales Joint Task Force into Drug Trafficking. Furthermore, I am advised that an outline of the two reports appeared in the Melbourne Sun Herald of 13 March 1971.

In relation to the requested information on action taken by the authorities following receipt of those reports, I have been advised by my colleague, the Minister for Defence, that the first report resulted in subsequent disciplinary charges against certain members of the Australian Army. In respect of the second report, my colleague advised that the report had been requested by an officer of the then Department of External Affairs on 23 January 1971 and had been forwarded to the Secretary of that Department on 3 March 1971, for any further enquiry by that Department in relation to the Australian Embassy in South Vietnam.
